louis 02/24/2021 10:04 AM
@zer0tweets how can we trust the band 48 UE reports from cells?
10:04
ie: what keeps them from reporting arbitrary numbers to maximize POC rewards?
mfalkvidd 02/24/2021 10:04 AM
Gaming: I can fairly easily set up a SDR to emulate an UE and try to attach with a new IMSI every time. Will the attachment require an approval from the HLR? (in that case, emulated UE would not be counted so it wouldn't be a problem.)
10:06
I bet FreedomFi is closely monitoring regulation progress in the US. Do you have any insight in similar support outside the US? Would be nice to prepare non-US support if possible.
10:09
btw, I use wifi calling daily. Handover works good, but I hear a small change in the noise level; my guess is that the different networks use using different audio codecs.
capcom 02/24/2021 10:13 AM
yea, wifi calling is far better for me
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:29 AM
lot's of valid questions on "gaming"... we have some ideas on how to make it harder and will post some updates.... anybody else has good ideas on how to minimize "gaming" please chime in
1
JMF 02/24/2021 10:30 AM
The simplest form of PoC rewards is to treat each as a lone wolf and split the excess DC rewards until there are data based rewards.
10:31
Or some HIP 15/17 variation that takes into account density around you.
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:31 AM
I think for starters we can split the task of "solving for gaming" into two parts... 1) how do you verifiably proof that "there is a cell radiating any signal" 2) how do you prove that it's in a good location
10:32
1. is very easy with CBRS because all CBRS cells are controlled by SAS. We can have validators query SAS api and see the very real picture of what's happening
10:33
...downside of above approach is that it's not portable to other frequency bands... and ideally we'd like portable approach. but as a starting point, it could work
10:34
2. there are plenty of easily accessible data sources on where there is demand for 5g/lte (that MNOs use to do RF planning)
10:34
...so we can adjust what the cell is reporting through a filter
10:35
validator nodes can run "SAS verification" and "IMSI spammer" verification service... i.e. if somebody in Alaska forest is reporting they have crazy demand, then it will be just automatically adjusted by the verification service on validator nodes
10:36
plus we have rewards ceiling per cell
10:36
the goal is to make it such that gaming is not economically viable
PaulM 02/24/2021 10:37 AM
Here's an orthogonal question - do we need PoC for LTE? There is already plenty of demand for LTE will the DC earns sufficient incentivize the build out? Lorawan was different in there is not as much use / demand so the network needed to be bootstrapped using PoC as an incentive.
ionberoiz 02/24/2021 10:38 AM
should we look to set up a time for a technical call? First few points: -Materials on where to deploy -Process of deployment and specs of each cell station. (A more detail look into back-haul requirements) -overall challenges and knowledge of system
PaulM
Here's an orthogonal question - do we need PoC for LTE? There is already plenty of demand for LTE will the DC earns sufficient incentivize the build out? Lorawan was different in there is not as much use / demand so the network needed to be bootstrapped using PoC as an incentive.
Bertie 02/24/2021 10:39 AM
This is a good point
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:40 AM
sure, let's setup a separate call. can @Scott.Nova maybe spin up a google doc space to add questions / discussion points to the agenda ?
Bertie
This is a good point
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:41 AM
There is plenty of demand for LTE, but not for Helium LTE
PaulM 02/24/2021 10:41 AM
BTW, I think this is an awesome idea - just playing devil's advocate
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:41 AM
so until we have a bunch of MNOs and MVNOs on the network, there will be no data. (edited)
1
Scott.Nova 02/24/2021 10:42 AM
You are probably looking for DeWi @scott not me. FYI
ionberoiz 02/24/2021 10:42 AM
is there a map where telcos usually look for offloading?
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:43 AM
ideally, we need to pick a city and get people to setup some meaningful coverage there... that would enables us to move faster with MNOs/MVNO interest we've seen so far and there needs to be a way to comp those first movers for their investments in small cells
ionberoiz 02/24/2021 10:44 AM

ionberoiz

zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:44 AM
kinda.... let me dig... there is a map of where telcos bid the most for CBRS PAL licenses
ionberoiz 02/24/2021 10:44 AM

10:44
we can look into that and perhaps look into amount of units, engineering solutions to deploy

zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:48 AM
Where MNOs bid for CBRS
JMA_Wireless_-_CBRS_PAL_Result_Maps.pdf
2.26 MB
ionberoiz
@zer0tweets whats the ballpark backhaul specs? Up/down and total monthly data consumption on average.?
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 10:49 AM
most small cells are 150Mbps DL 20Mbps UL - you can estimate backhaul based on that (edited)
10:50
we've added some thoughts on what would qualify as good backhaul for offload into the HIP
zer0tweets
most small cells are 150Mbps DL 20Mbps UL - you can estimate backhaul based on that (edited)

Bertie 02/24/2021 11:13 AM
To a certain degree. Higher demand leading to more competition to fulfill demand lowering overall costs makes some sense, though. On the other side of the coin thatâ€™s why so many rural areas donâ€™t have high speed internet, no one would be able to afford the costs most providers would have to charge to make it make sense from a business standpoint/also why smaller markets with less competition are able to charge so much in impoverished urban areas for low quality coverage.
JMF

1
Ditoboisy 02/24/2021 11:14 AM
Donâ€™t we need to be concerned about airway licensing? I skimmed through a lot of the comments and havenâ€™t seen anyone talking about it.
JMF 02/24/2021 11:15 AM
If I understand it correctly, there is non-priority bandwidth that is open for community use.
capcom 02/24/2021 11:15 AM
CBRS is unusual in my understanding of it. basically the spectrum is split into priority access licenses that carriers have paid for, and unlicensed traffic that is shared with anyone who uses it
hashc0de 02/24/2021 11:16 AM
Three priority levels. Military, PALS and community.
11:17
The SAS system that all cells need to report to get instructions on what they do based on that priority. For example if a navy ship comes in, all cells need to redirect and give way.
11:17
Itâ€™s not unlike air traffic control but for frequencies
JMF 02/24/2021 11:17 AM
Realistically we should probably pick a city with a lot of current gateway owners in it because pickup will be immediate.
capcom 02/24/2021 11:17 AM
yea, the SAS is a constant kind of communication rather than a one time interaction with the gateway

This is a collaborative document between the Helium community and FreedomFi, regarding discussion of HIP 27. Please add areas for discussion or specific technical questions that youâ€™d like to cover on a group call. FreedomFi Call Agenda: TBD Discussion Areas: Pilot city and how itâ€™s dete...

11:26

11:30

scott pinned a message to this channel. 02/24/2021 11:30 AM
ionberoiz 02/24/2021 11:31 AM

para1 02/24/2021 11:31 AM
this is super exciting and I have a lot of backscroll to read! on the hardware / availability front I would personally caution all-out speed... lets take the time to get this right, the economics need to be spot on before its live / main-net, gaming does need to be addressed (reading the hip it seems like "colluding gateways" style gaming might work fine here). Id say at least rev1 hardware early adopters need to be ok with "testnet only".... hopefully that constraint could be dropped but I wouldnt want to be locked into "well we sold 15k units with gaming potential but we cant turn them off without a riot so we are stuck now" (edited)
timtamothee
Local regulations for CBRS is definitely something I'd like to read up more on. It's not available nationwide then?
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:31 AM
CBRS is available nationwide to our knowledge. not sure what specific regulations in SF would preclude it
1
JMF
Yes talking about the hardware itself. It seems like rolling this out widely with maybe a few requirements (cities over 250k or whatever) would lead to natural centers of density like the helium network has now.
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:36 AM
the main concern with rolling out just everywhere is from the standpoint of "value of such network to an MNO/MVNO"... it makes little sense for an MNO to spent cycles on offloading into a network with .01% coverage in every city
11:36
it makes more sense if we could have a cluster that could meaningfully offload a macro cell tower in some particular location and then expand city by city
JMF 02/24/2021 11:37 AM
I get that, but opening to just a city doesnâ€™t necessarily mean density will be greater in that city as long as there are not production capacity constraints
capcom 02/24/2021 11:38 AM
@zer0tweets what do you think the price is of the lowest cost cbrs capable radio?
JMF 02/24/2021 11:38 AM
Once density is understood it provides options for negotiation with carriers
capcom 02/24/2021 11:38 AM
the gateway itself seems very cheap, could even be a Pi again
capcom
@zer0tweets what do you think the price is of the lowest cost cbrs capable radio?
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:40 AM
today it's $1K retail - https://www.ispsupplies.com/Baicells-PBS2120... but I am sure if we ordered more and direct (vs. channel) you can get discounts upwards 40-50%
capcom 02/24/2021 11:40 AM
does magmacore run on arm? i haven't tried yet
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:41 AM
generally speaking, consensus on the market is that in the next few years CBRS small cells should be be roughly on par with enterprise WiFi pricing wise
capcom
does magmacore run on arm? i haven't tried yet
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:41 AM
that's work on progress. ARM is working on it directly (and a member of Magma foundation)
capcom 02/24/2021 11:41 AM
excellent. so feasible that a pi-based gateway + commercial radio is a viable setup
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:42 AM
even better many of the radios (like the one I posted above) are arm based
capcom 02/24/2021 11:42 AM

zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:42 AM

@zer0tweets what's your guestimation on $ per gb that's feasible. I saw somewhere that MVNOs pay $2+ per gb for a lot of wholesale data plans. It seems like this may be something that is charged a premium?
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 11:54 AM

zer0tweets

11:57

para1 02/24/2021 11:57 AM

maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 12:01 PM

para1
the earning cap per gateway seems very gameable (its why I dont like it with LoRa either). just run "fake" 5G gateways in proximity of my one real gateway and round-robin whatever metric earns among them.
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 12:01 PM
running a fake CBRS cell is not possible because to radiate you'll need a grant from SAS which if if run a domain proxy on a "validator node" we can query if you have a SAS spectrum grant
JMF 02/24/2021 12:01 PM
realistically that's where it's gotta get to anyways
denis_a 02/24/2021 12:02 PM
Just as a side note, philosophically, we like that the Helium network is incentivized, informed and permission-less, the incentive needs to make sense and comparable to the lora gateways, we need to identify tools to inform us on where to place the cells for max effectiveness and we need to be able to place anywhere in the nation with no permission
maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 12:02 PM
So if you own a few hotspots in an area, you can say that the 10 dollar a month savings you can get would make it cheap.
maco2035 ðŸ®
Well lets say, you use it for yourself, put it on a few phones, and your hotspots.
para1 02/24/2021 12:02 PM
not profitable though unless you introduce arb, its basically acting as home wifi
12:02
your phone uses your 5G gateway instead of your wifi
zer0tweets
running a fake CBRS cell is not possible because to radiate you'll need a grant from SAS which if if run a domain proxy on a "validator node" we can query if you have a SAS spectrum grant
capcom 02/24/2021 12:02 PM
how does this process work? each gateway has to register with the SAS?
maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 12:02 PM
Yes
JMF 02/24/2021 12:03 PM
Random side note - if making DCs a stable coin is at all a consideration I think the ability to link these DCs to existing DCs will be important
maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 12:03 PM
You need a sas license. About 20 bucks a month.
capcom
how does this process work? each gateway has to register with the SAS?
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 12:03 PM
each cbrs cell must have a constant (every 60 seconds) heartbeat to SAS through IP network and SAS tells it on what channel to radiate (and move it to a different channel if there is conflict with millitary or PALs)
zer0tweets
running a fake CBRS cell is not possible because to radiate you'll need a grant from SAS which if if run a domain proxy on a "validator node" we can query if you have a SAS spectrum grant
para1 02/24/2021 12:04 PM
so that means i have a grant, not a gateway
12:04

maco2035 ðŸ®
@zer0tweets What is that critical mass number of routers you need to get a company to engage in roaming aggrements with you? Is it based on an area wise? So like in this part of the city, were congested, and we need some help, or is it like this suburb needs to be covered, and you can sell it to all the carriers for a bit.
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 1:26 PM
it can be both scenarios technically... i.e. urban densification or rural expansion (and we have both types in the mix that we are talking to); I would say for urban densification it has to be 500-1000 cells ideally clustered around a particular area
13:26
for rural expansion it can be just a couple cells in a particular area with no coverage (like we have deployments in national and state parks)
13:28
here is an article on 5g urban densification topic - https://seekingalpha.com/article/4407145-crown-castle-5g-poised-for-takeoff?utm_source=news.google.com&utm_medium=referral - verizon is doing deals like that with crown castle to contract out thousands of small cells (like 15K small cells in this case)
maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 1:28 PM
Gotcha
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 1:28 PM
so Helium could be a substitute to crown castle in this case

Anthonyra 02/24/2021 3:20 PM
Wouldn't the service provide that ROI? If there is a need than I don't think it would be too far fetched... in the current environment there are very few devices that "need" the coverage.. so by proving that there is coverage will drive the need for more devices that will than bring the rewards more to the DC side.. It's kinda the same thing that happened with bitcoin. The number of transactions on the network in the beginning wouldn't have been appealing enough for the miners to mine. So they offered newly minted bitcoin as an incentive. PoC would be good if the devices that were needed weren't there or if the Helium was requiring everyone to also provide the coverage. The HIP even agrees that this will be more pigeon holed than current coverage which makes me think that a) this will only be an option and not a requirement for new and current hotspots b) not something that will be implemented everywhere so how do you rate this coverage compared to LoRa coverage? Will it be out of the same reward pool? I'm thinking the latter is what's been thought about hence the need/want to cap the rewards at $1500/mo... which is in my opinion for a $1k investment absurd and will remove the $1500/mo from the rest of the network (edited)

zer0tweets 02/24/2021 4:22 PM
It doesn't need to be installed by a CPI, but the install needs to be verified by one. For our installs so far, we've been doing remote verification by asking people to send us pics of the installed cell

Tushar 02/24/2021 5:37 PM
the new hotspots and wireless protocols are growing the pie, not shrinking it. you have to think of mining in USD terms, not HNT terms. people used to mine 100s of BTC on their own in the early days. as new miners joined the network, they did not shrink the pie. they grew it for everyone and now Bitcoin is huge. I think the same thing is true of Helium, new miners will help make the whole network more valuable.
2
17:37
everyone who is in this chat right now is incredibly early
8
maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 5:40 PM
Yeah, I think that too.
Tushar 02/24/2021 5:40 PM
I think that the key insight which makes Helium possible is using proof of coverage and a token to kickstart the supply side of the network before the demand side is there. We've proven that can work for the LoRaWAN market which is a big deal. The 5G market is 1000x bigger than the LoRaWAN market. If we can apply our learnings as a community to 5G, we can really build something that changes the world. I think the 5G network will need proof of coverage rewards to get started. Otherwise it doesn't take advantage of the key insight which made the LoRaWAN network possible. (edited)
11
maco2035 ðŸ® 02/24/2021 5:42 PM
I think a crypto data services that an MVNO can use will be the most disruptive tech. Imagine a whole Network based on crypto.
17:42
You could make an MVNO that will be able to use a crypto at first, and have a fallback network on that
17:43
This would help people who live in remote areas so much
2
Tushar 02/24/2021 5:44 PM
yes that is certainly a great usecase (edited)
Tushar
I think that the key insight which makes Helium possible is using proof of coverage and a token to kickstart the supply side of the network before the demand side is there. We've proven that can work for the LoRaWAN market which is a big deal. The 5G market is 1000x bigger than the LoRaWAN market. If we can apply our learnings as a community to 5G, we can really build something that changes the world. I think the 5G network will need proof of coverage rewards to get started. Otherwise it doesn't take advantage of the key insight which made the LoRaWAN network possible. (edited)
Keenan 02/24/2021 5:46 PM
Well said!
Tushar 02/24/2021 5:47 PM
also just reducing cost for end users. mobile data plans are a major expense for so many people. i think Helium can help reduce the cost for those people because we can offer the service less expensively than ATT or Vodaphone ever can. We don't have a bunch of overpaid suits sitting in boardrooms and collecting $10M salaries. We don't have the bloated cost structure that the legacy providers have. That means we can offer the service cheaper and help people (edited)
2

Keenan 02/24/2021 5:49 PM
here in canada, we have notoriously high data rates, exacerbated by the lack of competition. we have 3 main telcos and they dont even try to compete with each other. lots of land to cover as well, so signal is usually not great. this would be a great use case for us up here!
Tushar
also just reducing cost for end users. mobile data plans are a major expense for so many people. i think Helium can help reduce the cost for those people because we can offer the service less expensively than ATT or Vodaphone ever can. We don't have a bunch of overpaid suits sitting in boardrooms and collecting $10M salaries. We don't have the bloated cost structure that the legacy providers have. That means we can offer the service cheaper and help people (edited)
zer0tweets 02/24/2021 5:49 PM
yes, exactly. the disparity in connectivity cost across various geographies is an indicator of the amount of bloat and bureaucracy that can be eliminated through this approach

jimv 02/24/2021 6:27 PM
Many elements of cellular networks are centralized like the packet core, RAN management, and inter-cell coordination. It's really interesting to imagine how far this tech can be pushed towards the decentralized model.
1
zer0tweets
my guesstimate would be >$1/Gb wholesale, but heavily depends on volume... the figure is pretty anecdotal, but definitely an area worth researching into more; whoever can contribute more data points would be great
jpad 02/24/2021 6:31 PM
Jon Chaplin of New Street has been putting Altice MVNO with Sprint at $2.25/GB and Comast/Charter MVNO with Verizon in the $4-5/GB range. These will change over time, but those are analyst numbers from 2020.
capcom
for example can IMSI/IMEI be verified in some way
jpad 02/24/2021 6:34 PM
IMEI can be verified, there are public databases. But you only get IMEI once you get further into the Attach call flow. So only for IMSIs that authenticate with the HSS. Usual place for IMSI is Security Mode Complete message in IMEISV. (edited)
capcom
5G will be a different technology stack completely, from the hardware to the server side. But it should all be open the same way

jimv 02/24/2021 8:33 PM
The FCC made the CBRS band accessible to unlicensed users in the US last year (no license/winning auction required). It's unique to the US.

jpad 02/25/2021 5:48 AM
Agreed on price is related to deals but i donâ€™t think Comcast traded spectrum. They sold spectrum to Verizon and gained the contractual right to an MVNO deal. Their $4-5 is general regarded as not sustainable. k0b13
From the HIP: "The goal of the experiment is to build a few clusters of CBRS infrastructure around a handful of urban locations and open such network to MNOs and MVNOs to offload their existing data traffic." I'm curious: what would the motivation be for existing MNOs to offload their backhaul like this, especially in areas where they already have coverage? Or is the idea to provide infra for new MNOs to enter the space and compete with the existing giants? (edited)
capcom 02/25/2021 6:12 AM
My understanding on this is that even when infrastructure is already deployed there are still significant costs to using it. For example crown castle and American tower are still charging per gb costs on â€œyourâ€ macro cell. There are also congestion concerns. Itâ€™s why carrier wifi (that annoying thing where your phone automatically connects to wifi networks sometimes) has become popular. Maybe @zer0tweets can weigh in as I am not an expert (edited)

zer0tweets 02/25/2021 7:01 AM
I think you summed it up nicely. Also, it takes a lot of power and capacity on macro towers to try and blast through the building walls, particularly in microwave bands which is why operators have to augment macro tower assets with in-building small cells

zer0tweets 02/27/2021 11:20 AM
ok, here is the "idea of the day" for improving the currently proposed approach for PoC in HIP 27 that is kinda a hybrid between community's suggestion of "let's only comp on data transfer"
11:21
what if we add a concept of "MNO/MVNO validator" into the mix... so prior to launching in a particular location, we get an MNO to run a "validator node"... that validator node would connect to an MNO HSS (via Magma FedGy) which is a much lighter weight MNO integration than full fledged offload
11:22
MNO-validator can certifiably check which of their authorized SIM cards are sending attach requests to a particular cell (but not yet go through full attach process and do data offload)
11:24
the level of hacking difficulty for that would be akin to "hacking yourself a free Verizon subscription" which I think sets a pretty tall bar for "hack proof PoC"
11:25
would be interested to hear what the community thinks about this
11:28
...above approach also has a big added benefit of providing a well-defined path for an MNO/MVNO to dip the toes into the network and assess the potential value of an offload solution without necessarily committing to doing offload... so the barrier to get more MNOs and MVNOs onboard is lowered that way
11:31
it also somewhat decreases the risk of building a small cell network that will have no MNO tenants, in that by requiring a MNO validator we'll be requiring a soft commitment from an MNO
Anthonyra 02/27/2021 11:37 AM
Could this be baked into the validator (Consensus Group)?
11:42
Where would this new validator fall under with the basic structure of Magma?
Anthonyra
Where would this new validator fall under with the basic structure of Magma?
hashc0de 02/27/2021 11:52 AM
Looks like it fits in the Fed-Gy / OCS area.
Anthonyra 02/27/2021 11:52 AM
Is a Fed-Gy a Federation Gateway then? haha
Anthonyra
Is a Fed-Gy a Federation Gateway then? haha
zer0tweets 02/27/2021 11:53 AM
yes
zer0tweets
MNO-validator can certifiably check which of their authorized SIM cards are sending attach requests to a particular cell (but not yet go through full attach process and do data offload)
hashc0de 02/27/2021 11:54 AM
I think this is interesting. Does the MNO need to run it or can anyone run it? This is similar to the oracle problem we talked about on Tuesday this week. How do we make sure that external data sources can be trusted by validators and other network participants in the Helium blockchain. Today we do something like this with oracled prices that maintain the exchange price between HNT and DC. We solve this by having 8 anonymous oracles submit prices that get normalized by the blockchain/consensus group to set the current price of exchange.
zer0tweets 02/27/2021 11:54 AM
Federation Gateway (aka FedGy) is basically a VM that connects magma to an existing MNO/MVNO core using standard Diameter based interfaces (like s6a) in case of LTE HSS
Anthonyra 02/27/2021 11:54 AM
I google searched "magma Fed-Gy" and it resulted in a lot of magma cakes... Okay would the Orchastrator be like the Router for the current network
hashc0de 02/27/2021 11:54 AM
This could also could be useful for SAS proxying. (edited)
hashc0de
I think this is interesting. Does the MNO need to run it or can anyone run it? This is similar to the oracle problem we talked about on Tuesday this week. How do we make sure that external data sources can be trusted by validators and other network participants in the Helium blockchain. Today we do something like this with oracled prices that maintain the exchange price between HNT and DC. We solve this by having 8 anonymous oracles submit prices that get normalized by the blockchain/consensus group to set the current price of exchange.
zer0tweets 02/27/2021 11:55 AM
In this model an MNO/MVNO would need to act as a validator and run the validator node
hashc0de 02/27/2021 11:56 AM
How often does the dataset/mapping of "authorized SIM->carrier" change?
Anthonyra 02/27/2021 11:57 AM
Why would "they" need to run it? Wouldn't that add some centralization? What about maybe a transaction that can act like a contract that they can use? (edited)
hashc0de 02/27/2021 11:57 AM
it's still centralized if only they can update the dataset.
11:58
I don't think there's a centralization problem here. the whole point is that there's a list and only they really know about that list.
11:58
Whether or not they run a validator for it or they just submit transactions to update it (like an OUI routing table update) is an implementation detail, i think.
Anthonyra 02/27/2021 11:58 AM
I'm probably lacking in the technical knowledge probably will need to dig around Magma a bit more and even MNO/MVNO for that matter
hashc0de 02/27/2021 11:59 AM
@zer0tweets today routers can push a routing table update (a xor filter) that tells the blockchain that they are accepting certain device ranges. miners use this information to route packets to them.
12:01
i'm not sure if this data fits into a filter but could be a potential way for an MNO or MVNO to say affirmatively that they service that SIM.
hashc0de
Whether or not they run a validator for it or they just submit transactions to update it (like an OUI routing table update) is an implementation detail, i think.
zer0tweets 02/27/2021 12:54 PM
there a few things to consider for the design here 1. MNO/MVNO cannot and will not share individual sim data with anybody. 2. MNO/MVNO would not open multiple tunnels to 3rd parties to connect to their network core
12:55
perhaps there is something we can devise where sim data is cryptographically encoded and exposed such that other parties can validate without actually knowing sim data details
4
hashc0de 02/27/2021 12:56 PM
This sounds interesting. I agree that we shouldnâ€™t let it be totally open. Potentially some PII leakage issues there.
12:56
But we also need a way for any validator or chain participant to verify data.
zer0tweets
it also somewhat decreases the risk of building a small cell network that will have no MNO tenants, in that by requiring a MNO validator we'll be requiring a soft commitment from an MNO

SralP 02/28/2021 9:14 AM
@zer0tweets I just took a short dive into German regulations about 5G frequencies. A person can obtain a license to operate a wireless broadband station between 3.7GHz - 3.8GHz and 24.75GHz and 27.5GHz. But this does atleast cost 1000â‚¬ and is further depending on the purchased bandwidth, duration and area it is covering (domestic area is factor 6 more expensive than rural).
09:15
And you need to own that piece of land if I am correct.
maco2035 ðŸ®
But needs more people to sign ahead right?
zer0tweets 02/28/2021 1:45 PM
I think that having a mechanism whereby we get soft commitments from partners to offload into the network as a prerequisite for deployments is a good thing; it will ensure we are building out in locations relevant to offload partners and will greatly increase the probability of actual data usage

But this does atleast cost 1000â‚¬ and is further depending on the purchased bandwidth, duration and area it is covering (domestic area is factor 6 more expensive than rural).

TechMon 03/05/2021 2:18 PM
https://www.fiercewireless.com/private-wireless/tucson-stands-up-cbrs-network-help-from-insight-jma-geoverse-and-tilson
Tucson stands up CBRS network with help from Insight, JMA, Geoverse...
Using city-owned assets, Tucson was able to deploy a CBRS network quickly to meet the needs of homebound citizens who lacked high-speed internet.
3

zer0tweets 03/08/2021 5:47 PM
This one looks like it primarily focuses on fixed wireless access using CBRS; that can be another use case from operator offload for Helium, but would require us to think through proof of coverage yet again... the upside on this use case is it's likely faster to roll out vs. dealing with MNO integrations

zer0tweets 03/11/2021 10:11 PM
If you are building your won CBRS Fix Wireless network and are also responsible for charging the customers directly, what is the point of doing it on Helium? We have a lot of CBRS FWA customers and if we can crack the economic puzzle on this, it could be an easy shoe-in

zer0tweets 03/11/2021 10:12 PM

maco2035 ðŸ®

zer0tweets 03/11/2021 10:13 PM
Right, Magma is the core. MVNO/MNO can still have their own core and Magma has an implementation for integrating with an existing core and extending it for the MNO offload use case

ajh 03/17/2021 6:08 AM
Hi - I work in CBRS and in my personal time I've run a helium hotspot since last year. Have also built and sold carrier wifi offload networks for years. Super excited to see folks working on combining these, and would love to help where I can. Are there any canonical docs other than the GitHub link and meeting minutes?
5
pharkmillups 03/17/2021 6:22 AM
@ajh Hi there.
06:24
Nothing else in the way of docs right now but that should change soon.
06:25
What gets you excited about Helium + CBRS?
ajh 03/17/2021 9:21 PM
Thanks. Short term: Excited about Helium in a neutral-host context - radios as miners help recoup upfront investment, which could make speculative CBRS deployments more appealing to real estate owners. Also seeing a lot of initial interest in CBRS for private IOT apps - seems like a good fit for Helium from the client side, given its LoRa/IOT background.
21:24
Long term it's got the makings of a working, distributed spot market for general wireless connectivity. I think there are a lot of gotchas along that path but it's exciting to contemplate.
4

Michael Keating 04/05/2021 7:16 PM
US Ignite, one of the groups behind this, is an alliance of big telco operators and suppliers. Sidewalk Infrastructure Partners, another supporter, is a big Google-backed future-of-infrastructure fund investing in capital-intensive long-term things like toll roads for autonomous vehicles.

zer0tweets 04/07/2021 9:23 AM
the entire issue of whether an ISP can legally enforce a consumer to use the bandwidth the consumer has paid for towards this or that is very contentious; in my view, if our experiment gets to the scale where ISPs start to notice and worry about it, we've already won and it will be easier for ISPs to find a way to embrace the effort rather than try to sue and stop it
1
zer0tweets
the entire issue of whether an ISP can legally enforce a consumer to use the bandwidth the consumer has paid for towards this or that is very contentious; in my view, if our experiment gets to the scale where ISPs start to notice and worry about it, we've already won and it will be easier for ISPs to find a way to embrace the effort rather than try to sue and stop it
scott 04/07/2021 9:24 AM
I tend to agree with this. They'll want a piece of the action before they try to police it.
1
zer0tweets 04/07/2021 9:26 AM
right, if anything, it's an opportunity for most ISPs vs. a threat... ISPs have long been trying to eat into the MNO market share and this could be a path
Tushar 04/07/2021 10:40 AM
also I think if terrestrial ISPs become a problem, space based ISPs are the alternative solution
1
Kekupaa 04/07/2021 12:36 PM
My understanding is that ISPs fall under the Telco Act of 1996 which means they could not stop this legally.
12:39
This is only for the U.S. My old company use to use this all the time for being able to provide services in locations they did not own the infrastructure.
Golan7 04/07/2021 2:14 PM
If this HIP is approved will we need compeletely new miners\mashines? And also new 3rd party developers as well...?
Golan7
If this HIP is approved will we need compeletely new miners\mashines? And also new 3rd party developers as well...?
zer0tweets 04/07/2021 2:48 PM
it won't affect anything for existing Lorawan mining; for earning on 5g traffic, it will require a separate hotspot; we are exploring porting Magma to arm, which could make it possible to reuse most of the existing miners for running localized network core and miner software, but you'll still need a 5g radio to plug into it

NJ 04/14/2021 8:27 PM
I think I take the opposite view. â€œAs a good rule of thumb, proprietary technology must be at least 10 times better than its closest substitute in some important dimension to lead to a real monopolistic advantage.â€ -Peter Thiel
20:29
Helium (LoRa) is way more than 10x better on data/$, big reason why I like this project so much. $0.50 a gb is hardly competitive (edited)
20:30
Voting for a rework on this hip
xodpox
I found this article interesting. Any comments? https://www.einnews.com/pr_news/538531818/expeto-completes-10-million-financing-to-advance-its-enterprise-first-private-mobile-nextworking-platform
ferebee 04/15/2021 5:51 AM
That is fascinating. Reading the press release, it sounds like they might be competing with Helium, but upon further investigation, they are complementary and asymmetric. Their â€œNeXtworkingâ€ platform about is extending private enterprise edge networks through private LTE/5G etc. buildout and integrating existing public mobile network infrastructure into a managed private network. Helium via HIP-27 is looking to extend public networks.
05:55
In other words, expeto.io is about extending private networks over public infrastructure, while Helium is about extending public networks over private infrastructure. I wish somebody above my pay grade would comment on this. Where is Horace Dediu when you need him? Paging @Kekupaa
JMF 04/15/2021 7:48 AM
@NJ for me it depends on who the customer is. In this case the customer that matters out of the gate are the big 3 wireless carriers. That's what I think is being missed. Right now those carriers pay $2 to $8 (pulling some old numbers from discussions) per GB. We are not implementing a new technology, just democratizing the expansion of it, so I don't believe it makes sense to try to undercut the existing roaming options by a factor of 4 right out of the gate. It just means the payback on the units is going to be 4 times longer. In this case there are very real infrastructure costs to those implementing the small cells.
07:49
The "key differentiator" of Helium is not the tech it's the ability to get coverage where other networks can't. We don't need to compete on price to have a 10X advantage over existing systems, in fact competing on price may hurt the systems ability to scale rapidly, which would hurt the key differentiator.
07:50
It seems like we're trying to price this like we're going to sell it as an MVNO service, which is hilariously far off compared to the massive opportunity of selling to the carriers as a roaming partner out of the gate.
07:55
Does that assessment of current customer sound right to everyone? The consumer LTE plan comp doesn't make any sense to me.
6
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 8:13 AM
Also Helium LoraWAN is about $54/gb..
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 8:14 AM
I agree with your assessment. I would also like to add that Telco Resellers would find great value in Helium since for them it comes down to usage cost. They have to pay for infrastructure anyways since they typically don't own a lot so if it is cheaper for them to provide the same service to customers through Helium then ILECs then I am sure they would adopt.
Anthonyra
Also Helium LoraWAN is about $54/gb..
capcom 04/15/2021 8:15 AM
it's irrelevant to measure lorawan per gb, as that amount of traffic never gets moved

capcom 04/15/2021 8:17 AM
he's talking about HIP27: While it is clear that weâ€™ll need to tweak the pricing for CBRS data as we get more data and better understand the market economics, it is suggested that we initially set the price of passing 1GB of CBRS data through Helium network at $.50 per GB or $.00000003 per LTE packet of 66 bytes.
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 8:18 AM
Ah well the sentence above is structured to elude to being in regards to LoRa and not the 5G/LTE being discussed (edited)
08:20
In regards to picking a â€œpriceâ€ point why not make it possible for the individuals standing it up to pick per DC conversion? And not rely on a centralized agreement of sorts?
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 8:22 AM
I personally think that would be a very hard sell to adopters. Imagine trying to track all the different charges depending on local. I use to be a Cost Analyst for a Telco and just thinking of that makes my head hurt.
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 8:23 AM
Just set it up where you set the max youâ€™re willing to pay. If thereâ€™s none available thereâ€™s no service. Build in competition also
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 8:25 AM
Good point but then degradation of service could become and issue. Don't get me wrong it is possible and we use to have to do that for each mom and pop shop that owned infrastructure but I see that problem being compounded exponentially with Helium since there would be so many different people owning CBRS nodes.
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 8:26 AM
If an owner sees the going rate as $0.50 they would set theirs the same if they want data to be transferred (edited)
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 8:38 AM
I understand where you are coming from. I personally like the stationary price similar to how DC translates to $ now for ease of pricing. I think stationary pricing also allows for anyone to participate in network growth without the threat of others coming in and undercutting prices in high usage areas just to get the traffic.
2
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 8:45 AM
But those undercuts lead to better prices for the users. Look at the Uk and their wireless services. Look at why the US government required T-Mobile to help create Dish into a wireless provider when they absorbed Sprint. Competition is good and I think itâ€™s self policing. But at the end of the day itâ€™s up to the community to decide whatâ€™s best (edited)
capcom 04/15/2021 8:50 AM
a few people have suggested that you should be able to charge variable amounts of DC. i dont hate it. but i also understand the problem, as its much less predictable for users. possible you could overcome that with good UI
2
ferebee 04/15/2021 8:53 AM
simplicity wins
capcom 04/15/2021 8:56 AM
yea, but it is also true that not all coverage is equal. if i somehow get a CBRS gateway inside an airport, that would be more valuable than one in an empty cul de sac
08:56
maybe the increased usage is sufficient reward
3
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 8:59 AM
A couple extra months of engineering to make the system self policing and controlling might save multiple DeWi changes and updates to the core. Also not all regions are the same when it comes to internet costs. For example, $100/mo in rural Michigan gets you at most 40mbps. Why try to have a community come up with best cost when the node installers could? If they set one up and ask $10/gb theyâ€™d get no service. Which is the only way to get rewarded without PoC
1
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 9:10 AM
You both make great points. Thanks for bringing them up. I will definitely think on this more.
carlo.acutis 04/15/2021 10:25 AM
I have a newb question: if it is successful, would this proposal work with the Nebra hotspot or only certain of the other hotspots?
arskiracer 04/15/2021 10:31 AM
If the goal is to maximize coverage and/or speed, it seems the incentive should be based on those aspects. Allowing individual price controls seems it could incentivize the absolute lowest price, which could result in lowest quality hardware and service. In other words, this could result in very inexpensive service at the cost of network quality. (edited)
10:38
Although, that same argument could be made for consumer electronics, and we do see that often many companies will sell products very inexpensively, undercutting competitors, but the products end up being very poor quality. But people then tend to learn and not buy those products. I guess then going back to Helium, the question becomes, would users of the network then want to set a minimum price to ensure quality service, or would the high speed Helium network simply be labeled as a poor service in general, directing users back to traditional corporate providers?
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 10:48 AM
I agree with the consumer electronics statement. I think Helium has a good thing going right now with approving manufacturers to build to spec. I would like to see that carried over to CBRS nodes to maintain quality standards.
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 10:50 AM
For me I want to see this flexibility get extended to the LoRa also.. but thatâ€™s just me and wanting something truly decentralized
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 10:50 AM
I understand it is not a true decentralized viewpoint but I do think quality and consistency is key for marketing a service
Anthonyra 04/15/2021 10:52 AM
In terms of implementation I bet this will simply be an â€œantennaâ€ upgrade. Unless you buy a node specific to your use case.
carlo.acutis
I have a newb question: if it is successful, would this proposal work with the Nebra hotspot or only certain of the other hotspots?
Greg 04/15/2021 11:43 AM
New hotspots would be required that were specific to cbrs. Edit: existing hotspots may be capable of handling this. (edited)
Greg 04/15/2021 11:53 AM
Based on my reading, this HIP is asking for approval to build a neutral host CBRS network as a small pilot program. I have no issues with exploring this and think it's super exciting, but I think there are other items that are very high priority like moving the consensus groups to validators. Is there any estimate for resource allocation for this project? Would core Helium engineering time be required to build this out? If this is can be handled by a small, independent group to research and come back with a more concrete plan and HIP I think this would be great. I don't think anyone's suggesting this but I'd like to throw it out there explicitly that I wouldn't like to see the spotlight shift away from current priorities to focus on this.
Kekupaa 04/15/2021 11:58 AM
If the goal is for Helium to be as decentralized as possible then Dynamic pricing makes perfect sense. If the goal is to increase data transfer faster then I think Static pricing is easier to sell since consumers can base their financial models off a set price for adoption. An alternative method would be a hybrid pricing model where you set a ceiling price for data but allow owners to price below that ceiling. Then consumers would at least have their price for financial modeling and owners could set their own prices to an extent. I know this unfortunately wouldn't help the person paying an exorbitant amount for internet but it is just a thought.
Greg
New hotspots would be required that were specific to cbrs. Edit: existing hotspots may be capable of handling this. (edited)
capcom 04/15/2021 12:03 PM
not necessarily...

odlaetet 04/27/2021 8:40 AM

BABALONI 04/27/2021 8:40 AM

capcom 04/27/2021 8:41 AM
the problem is more that the spectrum is licensed, so only people who own it can use it. CBRS is a big deal here because it's unlicensed spectrum that existing cellphones support, and is big enough bandwidth to actually run cellular in
08:41
hopefully other countries follow suit
08:41
if not, wifi will work too. carrier wifi is a thing

K4mikz3 04/27/2021 10:11 AM
I want to use FreedomFi for my Private LTE/5G network and donâ€™t want to mine HNT. Is that still possible? Yes. HNT mining is a new, optional capability that can be switched on and off. Traditional FreedomFi Gateways with no mining or LoRa module are still available for sale and immediate shipping on FreedomFi website for $299. FreedomFi remains committed to its mission of helping customers build cost efficient and secure Private 5G networks with open source software and commodity hardware

tankmann
Hey all - just checking - If I get it right this FreedomFi Gateway is only available for within the US right? No chance to participate from Europe?
K4mikz3 04/27/2021 10:14 AM
I live outside of the US. Can I still buy FreedomFi Gateway and participate in mining rewards for mobile data offload? Not at this time. Our initial release focuses on mobile data offload using CBRS spectrum band, which is only available in the US. As we expand into Wi-Fi based mobile data offload and add new data roaming partners and radio vendors, weâ€™ll be rolling out the services in countries out of the US. Expect to hear more towards the end of 2021.
10:15
that's per official website
tankmann 04/27/2021 10:15 AM

jcarl 04/27/2021 10:23 AM
Will there be any partnerships/recommended vendors for the radios/small cells that attach to the FreedomFi gatway? A basic google search shows there are very few consumer options, looks like it is mostly enterprise. (edited)
jcarl
Will there be any partnerships/recommended vendors for the radios/small cells that attach to the FreedomFi gatway? A basic google search shows there are very few consumer options, looks like it is mostly enterprise. (edited)
K4mikz3 04/27/2021 10:27 AM
Do I need anything in addition to FreedomFi Gateway to earn HNT for mobile data offload? Yes. In addition to the FreedomFi Gateway you will need to buy a radio, certified to operate in the CBRS band. We are currently working with a number of CBRS radio manufacturers to certify their productsâ€™ compatibility with FreedomFi Gateway and the Helium network. We expect the radios to cost between $500 and $5000, depending on radio signal strength and throughput capabilities. The more powerful and expensive radios will enable owners to mine more HNT rewards.
10:28
We are currently working with a number of CBRS radio manufacturers to certify their productsâ€™ compatibility with FreedomFi Gateway and the Helium network.

gazmcghee 04/28/2021 12:59 AM
Please consider this peer reviewed science journal article, which says that some 5G frequencies ie "millimetre" wave heat insect bodies due to simple resonance - their body length matches the wave length. Is millimetre wave necessary or desirable from a technical point of view? BTW, Ive seen over 100Mbps on 4G. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-22271-3
Exposure of Insects to Radio-Frequency Electromagnetic Fields from ...

Here are some band 48 (CBRS) devices: Apple's iPhone 11s, Google's Pixel 4 phones, LG's G8 ThinQ, Motorola phones with the 5G Moto Mod, the OnePlus 7 Pro, and Samsung Galaxy S10 series all include support for the new band. Also, WTF is "OnGo"? That just makes me pissed off. We needed another name other than CBRS? Not consumer friendly enough? (edited)

KOWOP 04/28/2021 8:09 AM
5G has orders of magnitude more demand than LoRa, so that consumption model would indicate that the large majority of HNT rewards (again limited) would go to the 5G network. Is that a fair statement?
capcom 04/28/2021 8:09 AM
5G rewards are only for data credits spent, not proof of coverage. so the only way 5G hotspots get rewarded is when HNT is purchased by carriers and burned in to data credits to pay for that usage. to have that kind of HNT demand is a very good thing. if it turns out that no one uses the 5G network, then nothing changes - all the HNT rewards are PoC and still go to lorawan hotspots
1
KOWOP 04/28/2021 8:10 AM
Its a good thing for the 5G operators - not good for all the 200K LoRa hotspots
capcom 04/28/2021 8:10 AM
so yes, if there is massive traffic on the 5G network, there are less PoC rewards going to lorawan hotspots. but at the same time there is substantial demand for HNT to pay for the 5G traffic, which creates more value for the whole network
08:10
and of course we'd expect lorawan usage to continue to ramp up over time too, that's not going to stop
KOWOP 04/28/2021 8:11 AM
You are conflating the value of HNT with usage of the network (edited)
NJ 04/28/2021 8:11 AM

capcom 04/28/2021 8:11 AM
im not conflating anything. i'm explaining how it works. you can reach your own conclusion and interpretation of whether that is a good or bad thing

rawrmaan 04/28/2021 11:04 AM
Basically, no itâ€™s not a concern. Supply are and demand are at play. At the current market cap, youâ€™d need to burn ~$14m (or about 28,000,000GB 5G data at the proposed price of $0.50/GB) of Data Credits to deflate the supply by 1%
1
11:05
And that doesnâ€™t even take into account Net Emissions, which would prevent some of the deflation
WestheLion 04/28/2021 11:49 AM
And that's also why HNT is not a static price. If more DC is needed to be consumed, the price of HNT can increase so that more DC is available per HNT. For instance, if HNT is $1, then burning 1 HNT you'll receive $1/.00001 - 100k DC. If HNT is $10, then burning 1 HNT you'll receive $10/.00001 - 1million DC.
rawrmaan
Basically, no itâ€™s not a concern. Supply are and demand are at play. At the current market cap, youâ€™d need to burn ~$14m (or about 28,000,000GB 5G data at the proposed price of $0.50/GB) of Data Credits to deflate the supply by 1%
Steve (dewigo.com) 04/28/2021 12:09 PM
you did the math...awesome. 28M gb, divided by average 5gb per month per person, is only about 6 million people's worth of usage in a month. that sense of scale really doesn't seem insane if Helium 5g execution is half as good as the LoRa deployment. Burning 1% of supply per month seems like a huge amount of burn to me but I dont have anything to base this off.
12:10
this is a really fascinating way of connecting token economics to people's mobile data consumption. sounds like a winning proposition to me lol

You forgot that the price of a data credit is based on the oracle. So if the oracle says a hnt worth a billion dollars, then each hnt burned would give you a billion dollars of data credits. And then that would give you 2 billion gigabytes of lte data to transfer

JMF 04/28/2021 1:12 PM
Just caught up on this, fwiw I do think that there should be an incentive model for the CBRS units on top of DC usage. I may be wrong here when we know final price and how many people will buy just because they think itâ€™s awesome but I think the economics of $0.50/gb could get tricky without a POC-like mechanism. Personally I donâ€™t think the pricing needs to undercut the market by that much because the value of the network lies in its reach. If reach is limited by the return, the lower cost ends up hurting the main differentiator. On the other hand if thereâ€™s a POC-like mechanism it could in theory subsidize the 5G cost (and revenue) per GB, so I wouldnâ€™t be as worried. (edited)
13:14
Imo you could be at $1 to $2 per Gb and still be the lowest cost option 95% of the time AND still have a PoC option to further help incentivize the deployment.
13:16
In summary, I think the main focus should be incentivizing roll out, because access is the biggest differentiator. Being 10% or 25% or whatever the low end of the current market is sort of an unnecessary advantage when the customer base (carriers) are most interested in access and it could be detrimental if itâ€™s reducing total return to the network. (edited)

JMF 04/28/2021 1:46 PM
Followup to my last point: I do think the rewards for CBRS and other new bandwidths should be restricted to the â€œoverflowâ€ of the DC rewards that currently go to PoC. It can be thought of as the premium over equilibrium price that market speculation allows us to invest in new bandwidths.
13:49
@Lymph Iâ€™m not the technical expert here but Iâ€™ve heard a few ideas. Personally I think a simplified system would do great. Make all the PoC rewards a type of â€œchallengerâ€ reward. If a 5G device tries to connect with the node in an epoch itâ€™s considered â€œliveâ€ and qualifies for a challenger reward, then split rewards between the number of challengers (or whatever theyâ€™re called). Trying to look at how many devices try to connect and things like that opens it up to gaming imo, so Iâ€™d leave it simple with a 1 or 0 per epoch.
13:50
So not true PoC but proof that the node is somewhere of marginal value. The DC heavy devices will still make way more rewards, itâ€™s just a way of subsidizing the reduced data revenue being proposed.
Lymph 04/28/2021 1:51 PM
interesting
JMF 04/28/2021 1:54 PM
Once pricing info on the units and installations come out weâ€™ll know more but at $5k all in which is a semi feasible number (lower than current installations but higher than estimates with manufacturing volume) it could require something like 100k â€œvisitor hoursâ€ to have a return on a unit at $0.50/gb. I define a visitor hour as one person who is likely to connect roaming into the area of the node for 1 hour. Assuming the value add access of these is limited to a cafe or library or whatever, thatâ€™s a lot of people and potentially a long payback. (edited)
13:56
This was based on the only high level community WiFi bandwidth data I could find which was based on the data used on the network at the 2019 Super Bowl. About 70% of people connected to the WiFi and on average each person used about 100 mb per hour. You could argue people would use more data in other settings or less but thatâ€™s the data I had on hand.

linagee 04/28/2021 2:16 PM

gazmcghee
Please consider this peer reviewed science journal article, which says that some 5G frequencies ie "millimetre" wave heat insect bodies due to simple resonance - their body length matches the wave length. Is millimetre wave necessary or desirable from a technical point of view? BTW, Ive seen over 100Mbps on 4G. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-22271-3
gazmcghee 04/28/2021 5:07 PM
CBRS = 3.5Ghz = 8.5mm wavelength so I suppose safe for insects, but people want millimetre wave for speed.

lucatz70 04/29/2021 5:23 AM
carriers pay big money for spectrum...how would this circumvent that. FCC and CRTC would require same licences for spectrum no?
lucatz70
carriers pay big money for spectrum...how would this circumvent that. FCC and CRTC would require same licences for spectrum no?
Anthonyra 04/29/2021 5:30 AM
The key is the CBRS part. https://www.fcc.gov/35-ghz-band-overview
3.5 GHz Band Overview
In 2015, the Commission adopted rules for shared commercial use of the 3550-3700 MHz band (3.5 GHz band). The Commission established the Citizens Broadband Radio Service (CBRS) and created a three-tiered access and authorization framework to accommodate shared federal and non-federal use of the band. Rules governing the Citizens Broadband Radio ...
lucatz70 04/29/2021 5:33 AM
i think Canada may be much different...:( Although it is the same frequency band, 3.5 GHz spectrum in Canada is different from CBRS in the United States in that the spectrum licenses will be exclusive. There wonâ€™t be any dynamic spectrum sharing. In Canada, some existing users will retain their licenses.
lucatz70
carriers pay big money for spectrum...how would this circumvent that. FCC and CRTC would require same licences for spectrum no?
Bertie 04/29/2021 6:23 AM

CBRS allows you to broadcast your own radio without winning a PAL auction. Itâ€™s specifically intended to be used by â€œcitizensâ€
06:38
The PAL auction gave some carriers priority on the band. The military still has highest priority.

Tushar 04/29/2021 5:52 PM
$0.50 per GB is the price the HIP recommended as a starting price to access the CBRS network. The network will be able to adjust the pricing in the future and can even set pricing on a per region basis (edited)

Steve (dewigo.com) 04/30/2021 5:25 PM
i've listened to the community calls about 5G CBRS and its very cool. I'm getting a major "uber for telco" vibe here where the consumer internet becomes the backhaul for all the devices of the world. Have a view of an urban park? antenna in the window, earn some cash. Run a coffee shop? monetize your internet via cell signal instead of wifi nag screens. is this realistic? (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 04/30/2021 5:32 PM
Trying to wrap my head around the cost structure.. so an individual buys all the mining hardware and supplies the internet backhaul. Then, the a cellphone user roams onto the CBRS band due to signal quality/geography (seamless and unaware). The cell user consumes data, which is tracked by the users MVNO. Is the MVNO buying data credits at a rate of $.50/gb? then these data credits get sent to the CBRS miner? So its basically bandwidth arbitrage for the MVNO, since the backhaul is paid by the individual's cable plan?
17:36
Also, how amazing would it be if Google Fi was onboard as the first MVNO. they are investors in Helium after all
Steve (dewigo.com)
Trying to wrap my head around the cost structure.. so an individual buys all the mining hardware and supplies the internet backhaul. Then, the a cellphone user roams onto the CBRS band due to signal quality/geography (seamless and unaware). The cell user consumes data, which is tracked by the users MVNO. Is the MVNO buying data credits at a rate of $.50/gb? then these data credits get sent to the CBRS miner? So its basically bandwidth arbitrage for the MVNO, since the backhaul is paid by the individual's cable plan?
capcom 04/30/2021 5:38 PM
the MVNO would buy data credits (or HNT to burn in to data credits) to pay for the bandwidth. the CBRS miner would get paid in HNT at a rate equivalent to the amount of traffic they deliver
Steve (dewigo.com) 04/30/2021 5:39 PM
Presumably there is a ton of red tape and pain if I wanted to sell bandwidth to an MVNO today, without helium in the loop. (edited)
capcom 04/30/2021 5:40 PM
it's impractical to do individual deals like this. there are several regional offloaders (ie. Boingo in airports)
Steve (dewigo.com) 04/30/2021 5:41 PM

Steve (dewigo.com) 05/01/2021 10:09 AM
Can somebody help me explain this calculation: "Carriers typically pay up to $5 per GB". How does that compute? I can buy a data plan that supports 30gb/month from an MVNO at a cost of around $40 in the USA. Is there some kind of spectrum tiering? Ie, my MVNO data is bottom barrel cheapest & lowest quality, versus $5/gb would be the price for super fast 5g? That quote just doesn't make sense when I examine the wide range of data plans currently available.
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/01/2021 10:28 AM
Could there be a mechanism for dynamic pricing of 5g data credits? like surge pricing
hashc0de 05/01/2021 10:40 AM
Certainly could exist. I think there are a few steps along the way: - type tagged pricing like this. Lower cost for 5G vs lora. - dynamic pricing set by hotspot owners based on type. - flexible pricing based on sla set by hotspot owner with maybe some slippage or spot price range (think asks in an exchange) - flexible pricing accepted by packet buyers (slippage range here makes sense too, think bids in an exchange) - fully dynamic market with oracled price fed back to hotspot owners and packet purchasers.
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/01/2021 10:50 AM
imagine a mobile data derivatives exchange where cell data is just bought and sold, speculated, hedged. i wonder if that could ever happen outside the carrier monopoly
10:50
neat to think about. thanks @hashc0de
hashc0de 05/01/2021 10:51 AM
If global major airlines can participate in those types of markets for avgas/ jeta futures, this seems doable. Letâ€™s build it (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/01/2021 10:52 AM
paging sam bankman-fried
hashc0de 05/01/2021 10:52 AM
There will be intermediaries necessary along the way. Ones that provide insurance and SLAs
10:53

Badvoc 05/02/2021 11:47 AM
This is never going to be accepted in the UK. There's so much anti 5g feeling here that if people got the idea that hotspots were 5g it would kill the network rollout stone dead. Nobody is going to put a 5g transmitter in their home and certainly not in a window where it invites passing protesters to throw a brick. This is a stupid idea. It endangers both property and people especially as there is a nice easy to use location finder giving the locations of every hotspot in the country. They won't be bothering to check if the hotspot is 5g or not before the bricks get thrown or the intimidation starts. As soon as the idea gets about that hotspots are 5g nobody will be safe from the activists.
Badvoc

Nobody is going to put a 5g transmitter in their home and certainly not in a window where it invites passing protesters to throw a brick. This is a stupid idea. It endangers both property and people especially as there is a nice easy to use location finder giving the locations of every hotspot in the country. They won't be bothering to check if the hotspot is 5g or not before the bricks get thrown or the intimidation starts. As soon as the idea gets about that hotspots are 5g nobody will be safe from the activists.
capcom 05/02/2021 11:59 AM
good job it's not available in the UK mate
3
Badvoc 05/02/2021 12:18 PM
The worrying thing is it doesn't need to be. People don't read the articles, they read the headline. This is a country where a pediatrician got beat up because the local grunts didn't know the difference between a pediatrician and a paedophile. If the anti brigade see headlines about 5g hotspots, guess what? Suddenly every hotspot is 5g in their heads and everyone who owns one is a potential target, available in the UK or not. I've already had one person accuse me of pushing 5g even before the announcement about the new boxes. IMO it's a stupid idea and someone WILL get killed because of this.
3
capcom 05/02/2021 12:31 PM
what would be stupid is not launching something because we're worried about some idiots who don't know what 5G means. what would sir winston do?

mysteryan1987
Hello! I have a question regarding Ethernet cable and the helium mining for iot/5g aplications. I am planning to install hotpspots (iot) on top of 20-35 story buildings and want to make sure to run the right category ethernet cable, assuming I would maybe switch to the freedomfi miners when they become available here in canada. Would cat6 cable will ever be enough even for 5g, since it transfers way more data and also since my cable runs are going to be pretty long ? If someone knows and can give me insight on this it'd be very much appreciated. Thanks!
joeysmillican 05/02/2021 8:38 PM
All ethernet cable is typically rated for 100m or 330 feet for the advertised speed. If going father than this then it would recommend to use fiber optic cabling.

mysteryan1987

joeysmillican 05/03/2021 7:05 PM
I would say that it would be adequate. Considering that the Freedomfi Hotspot only supports a 1 GBPS port it would be more than enough. I would if you can get a qualifier to test that cable that would be awesome, guaranteeing the connection. Many things can go wrong with building your own cable, but if you plan to purchase a pre-fab cable then you should be good because they test them before leaving the warehouse. But you will still be limited by the 100 Meter rating. But at worse you may only go down to 1 gbps which would suffice. Testing will only be the way to know for sure.
acorn66 05/03/2021 9:50 PM
ok, final post for the night. just setup appt with comcast here in Texas. i live in major city.. they have business internet in my area. assume rural areas might not. something to look into. my question is pricing and terms for 1 gbps service at my home with dedicated line. Their off the wall sheet pricing is $500 and they state up to 1gbps. i have had comcast before and their service never reaches published speed. so, Terms were 2 year contract etc. $12 grand committment just for line. Alot of people are jumping on this 5g thinking it will be like im sure buying a $400 miner and plugging in and waiting for the returns. i think you should do some serious due deligence before willy nilly jumping on this. i am planning on doing mine before i make a decision. Being committed to a 2 year internet contract i might not need if this fails is not something to take lightly. some answers would be welcome from those who are proposing this. not just slick ads. thank you.
acorn66 05/04/2021 3:25 AM
Annother question please: i currently pay $70 mo for att internet. I get aversge 25down and 3-5 up. Its their 50 mb plan. I get 1 terrabyte cap. Or 1025 gb. If i take $70 divided by 1025 thats roughly .068 cents per g how or why will a telco pay $.50 cents / g ?
acorn66
Annother question please: i currently pay $70 mo for att internet. I get aversge 25down and 3-5 up. Its their 50 mb plan. I get 1 terrabyte cap. Or 1025 gb. If i take $70 divided by 1025 thats roughly .068 cents per g how or why will a telco pay $.50 cents / g ?
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/04/2021 8:01 AM
I think this is the heart of the value proposition. Bandwidth in the wireless spectrum is more expensive than the hard line variety, probably not only because the wireless is wireless but there may also be service agreements in place which guarantee a certain level of coverage and speed (which drives up the cost of deploying wireless, along with the traditional barriers to entry in the wireless spectrum). Helium is proposing to team up with freedomfi to introduce a new flavor of wireless coverage which is much cheaper but potentially less nice, starting with a few MVNOs in specific geography (to be determined). the cheap wireless price is afforded because individuals can use their hard line combined with the CBRS spectrum without super expensive barriers to entry (license). or so the theory goes. In practice i'm sure ISPs will take issue with an individual reselling their bandwidth, but the objective it to become so large it can't be ignored. its uber for bandwidth (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/04/2021 8:11 AM
if there is ever dynamic market pricing that could unlock some cool ideas like a starlink backhaul to 5g, make it portable and camp out at big gatherings like concerts, fairs, rallies, etc etc.
Steve (dewigo.com)
if there is ever dynamic market pricing that could unlock some cool ideas like a starlink backhaul to 5g, make it portable and camp out at big gatherings like concerts, fairs, rallies, etc etc.
acorn66 05/04/2021 8:29 AM
thank you steve. the issue with starlink is speed. beta is 100 to 150 mb. elon says 300mb coming soon after more sats in orbit. nothing ive read about 1-2 gb speeds with unlimited data. yes, someone should go by hawthrone and speak with someone there. elon's deal is for rural areas. starlink says their system may not be best suited for dense urban enviroments. i have decided to focus on the lorawan miners for now. I have looked at costs and deployment and too many unknowns at the momment IMHO. I will wait and see how all this pans out. If truly workable, they're will be plenty of opportunity in the future. i read report than there are over 13 million 5g hotspots needed to blanket the us. Now, are we talking 5g or 5g mmwave, the true high speed 5g( 800 mb or higher) has uber short range and trees, rain, people can block signal. i hope the Helium people really due their due diligence before marketing this as some easy peazy deployment. My research says otherwise. Also, i think unlike lorawan hotspot, this would be best suited for a business like llc etc. too many potential legal issues especially if your neighbors sue you because they think 5g is giving them bad health, an opinion many still debate. anyone can sue you and lawyers are expensive. For the telco technie this is a snap, for the hellium miner still struggling to figure out where to put his rak antenna, this could get quite frustrating. I wish helium the best and will hope they can come up with a viable plan that address all this issues and more.

Many things can go wrong with building your own cable, but if you plan to purchase a pre-fab cable then you should be good because they test them before leaving the warehouse. But you will still be limited by the 100 Meter rating. But at worse you may only go down to 1 gbps which would suffice. Testing will only be the way to know for sure.

Steve (dewigo.com)
I think this is the heart of the value proposition. Bandwidth in the wireless spectrum is more expensive than the hard line variety, probably not only because the wireless is wireless but there may also be service agreements in place which guarantee a certain level of coverage and speed (which drives up the cost of deploying wireless, along with the traditional barriers to entry in the wireless spectrum). Helium is proposing to team up with freedomfi to introduce a new flavor of wireless coverage which is much cheaper but potentially less nice, starting with a few MVNOs in specific geography (to be determined). the cheap wireless price is afforded because individuals can use their hard line combined with the CBRS spectrum without super expensive barriers to entry (license). or so the theory goes. In practice i'm sure ISPs will take issue with an individual reselling their bandwidth, but the objective it to become so large it can't be ignored. its uber for bandwidth (edited)

The_Professional 05/05/2021 8:30 AM
This isn't going to be for everybody. The planets need to line up in a sense to make this a viable thing for some. For me I have a location with cheap "rent" that I have miners on. Those miners will be swapped for 5g. There is already a 1 gbps business line which is 170 a month. The rent for that location is $150 a month. It's near a freeway and in an industrial area. For us adding 5g on this location will be pretty simple. Lol those words might come back to bite me. As far as starlink goes. SpaceX launched its last set of satellites in a higher orbit. From here on SpaceX is going to launch them into a lower orbit This will bring down the latency. Also, speed is controlled by software not hardware on starlink. Right now there's not enough satellites to boost the speed. They still need to launch 1500 more in the lower orbit but they had 2 launch's this month. They are making progress

linagee 05/05/2021 9:34 AM
Does partner traffic have to pop out of a partner network? Would they require endpoints encrypt traffic to go back to their network? If I was doing packet inspection, could I do any kind of attack against mobile user traffic? (Either just by packet inspection or packet injection.) Also, would partners require some level of uptime (like an SLA) from end point providers? Mobile handset traffic might not like getting packet loss or sudden disconnection. (It might be able to switch to another cell, but that might not be a fast process and give a bad experience.) Security and reliability are key. Does a SIM card already encrypt the mobile traffic to some depth inside a partner's network, or is the encryption/decryption at their radios? (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/05/2021 9:58 AM
Lots of questions, not much guidance yet. Frank Mong retweeted this just now, says they are working with several MNO and MNVOs, but whooo? https://www.rcrwireless.com/20210505/network-infrastructure/freedomfi-helium-blaze-new-5g-path-with-blockchain-network-deployment-model
Catherine Sbeglia
FreedomFi, Helium blaze 'new 5G path' with blockchain network deplo...
The blockchain network will run on CBRS spectrum and enable gateway hosts to mine cryptocurrency by providing 5G cellular coverage.

hs.EQ 05/05/2021 10:24 AM
https://support.google.com/sas/answer/9539380?hl=en
How the CBSD gets access to spectrum - SAS Help
CBSDs request a grant to reserve a portion of the spectrum for their use. If approved, the reservation has been made but the CBSD is not yet authorized to transmit using the grant. CBSDs periodic
linagee 05/05/2021 10:25 AM
Google orchestrates GAA "temporary licenses"? Spectrum Access System (SAS): Controls fundamental access to CBRS. Citizens Broadband Radio Service Device(CBSD): As per FCC, an eNodeB which is capable to support CBRS band is referred as Citizens Broadband Radio Service Device. Welcome Google overlords. (edited)
linagee
Does anyone know the "lease length" for CBRS GAA? Is it a number of hours? Days?

linagee 05/05/2021 10:40 AM
What kind of internet connection might you need for CBRS users if you're looking for the maximum throughput? Looks like around 200Mbps down / 10Mbps up. (And around 3 miles of coverage if your antenna is 20 ft from the ground and your terrain is flat, wow!) https://www.nctatechnicalpapers.com/Paper/2019/2019-on-the-performance-of-cbrs-fixed-wireless-access Comcast business internet is $134.90/mo for 200Mbps. (Based on some old price I found, so this may be way off.) (edited)

The_Professional 05/06/2021 12:47 PM
For us the infrastructure is already there for our paying customers. They pay us a monthly maintenance contract so we go out there at least once a month to make sure everything is running. I can't disclose how much we make on that but considering it's 60% of our income it's pretty good. We already do Lora sensors So for us to offload to our own gateway it's "free". There's already a 1 gbps connection. For us to add a 5G setup even with one radio it's only adding to the income. We already have connections with the property manager and there should be no reason that they're going to deny us installing a antenna on the roof. Especially down the line where IoT devices are CBRS compatible. The investment in this case is a little no-brainer. We have our customer paying us for a maintenance contract, we are mining helium, and data offloading 5G all from the one location. I'm only mentioning this so people can see where something like this would be beneficial. I don't see everybody installing a 5G hotspot on their mom's house. (edited)
