Chris 05/06/2021 5:04 PM
Joining in late here, but I love whatâ€™s planned! I thought @Steve (dewigo.com) raised great questions the other day about MVNOs and data pricing that didnâ€™t quite get addressed. Typically, true MVNOs that offer huge plans at low prices (e.g., 30GB for $40/month) are operating on a breakage model. A customer that uses his or her full 30GB of data isnâ€™t profitable for the MVNO, but the majority of customers donâ€™t use anything close to their full data allotments on these big plans. Also, a handful of the carriers that sometimes get called â€œMVNOsâ€ are really flanker brands owned by MNOs (e.g., Cricket, Visible, Metro). Flanker brands have MNO-style economics. For MNOs, the marginal cost of data is nearly $0 most of the time, but that changes drastically when a network is congested and data becomes a scarce resource. With both flanker brands and MVNOs, data is usually deprioritized. Deprioritized subscribers usually experience full-speed data, but their speeds may turn much slower than other users when a network is congested. (edited)
17:06
Relatedly, Iâ€™d like to give a strong vote of confidence to the dynamic pricing idea. The traditional model where a gigabyte of data is treated as identical to any other gigabyte of data regardless of where or when a subscriber uses the data is awfully detached from reality. If Helium could eventually tie the cost of data to congestion levels, it would be a real breakthrough in network efficiency (massively improving the incentive structure for both the networkâ€™s end users & those contributing coverage/capacity). Worth considering that the value an MNO gets from offloading traffic might fluctuate by orders of magnitude based on how congested its network is at any moment. (edited)
2
4
1
Chris
Relatedly, Iâ€™d like to give a strong vote of confidence to the dynamic pricing idea. The traditional model where a gigabyte of data is treated as identical to any other gigabyte of data regardless of where or when a subscriber uses the data is awfully detached from reality. If Helium could eventually tie the cost of data to congestion levels, it would be a real breakthrough in network efficiency (massively improving the incentive structure for both the networkâ€™s end users & those contributing coverage/capacity). Worth considering that the value an MNO gets from offloading traffic might fluctuate by orders of magnitude based on how congested its network is at any moment. (edited)
liddle framkie 05/06/2021 9:45 PM
great points.
Anthonyra 05/07/2021 5:36 AM
I was a strong advocate to have a bidding system for dynamic pricing since itâ€™s the best decentralized way of doing it. It can be seen as profit pendulum. Someone installs a LTE/5G micro cell and notices that thereâ€™s a demand in the area for it. They can set the cost to $1/gb letâ€™s say. The demand increases but supply decreases they could increase the cost per gb accordingly. If another host sees someone getting $2/gb they would be motivated to get a cell themself and probably will ask $1.5/gb the original hotspot would need to lower their cost to acquire traffic again. This would simply require users to set a max bid value for their account. If they can get access to data at their rate they get access. If not they might need to increase their max bid to get access. With this the only concern would be big players cutting cost to an unbelievable level smoking out the little guys. Thatâ€™s where a minimum floor (Id suggest $0.5/gb) would come into play
odlaetet 05/07/2021 6:55 AM
MasterMiner 05/07/2021 10:53 PM
Hello, I just joined this group, and I was reading some of the previous posts here. There may be some hype to this RF technology, and yes, I want to be part of this expansion to 5G for Helium. I also want to be realistic and share some of my personal experience and knowledge. That way, everyone here makes a better decision as to what is best for you. CBRS (Band 48) is a US-only spectrum. The 3.5 GHz to 3.7 GHz frequency is universal. In the US, all RF is controlled by the FCC. I am currently deploying a private LTE CBRS network and have tested a class B station at 120ft. The range is at half a mile with RSRP -110 dBm. I am using a two-sector array with 20 MHz each; in other words, the antennas am using are carrier-grade with the max output of 47 dBm. I also want to share that the type of deployment I am doing is slightly different because I am using CPE devices for internet use on the receiving end and not a LoRa (Low Latency Reliability Availability) IoT device.
22:59
odlaetet 05/08/2021 2:58 AM
@MasterMiner : You believe NB-iot greater future?
odlaetet
@MasterMiner : You believe NB-iot greater future?
MasterMiner 05/08/2021 6:04 AM
O yes, it's a lower frequency it has the range and penetration to cover a larger area.
odlaetet 05/08/2021 6:15 AM
So, in my home is a smart meter. Someone is reading every 15min some data. My meter tells NB-iot inside. Lora technology has longer history. Why?
MasterMiner 05/08/2021 6:33 AM
My personal experience is on the RF side of all of this. I have worked and currently working with enterprise companies in the deployment of LTE networks. I know Lora has been around for about 10 years. It is a nationwide movement for the smart city and even government grants. From a coverage standpoint and economics for a Utility company, having a device collect data and send it back is cost-efficient vs. the old school drive by collecting the same data. There are hundreds of devices the city owns working the same way. For NB-IoT and the current use, latency is not as important. Again am saying this with my experience.
odlaetet 05/08/2021 6:55 AM
sorry, i try to understand. Lora is good for my dogcollar (and a low latency-bonus ), and e.g. NB-iot for everything else? (edited)
odlaetet
sorry, i try to understand. Lora is good for my dogcollar (and a low latency-bonus ), and e.g. NB-iot for everything else? (edited)
MasterMiner 05/08/2021 7:05 AM
In our application, at least for me, LoRa is open at no cost to use. NB-IoT is a licensed LTE radio. Here is a good web page you can read more about the different uses. https://ubidots.com/blog/lorawan-vs-nb-iot/#:~:text=LoRaWAN%20is%20a%20low%20power,at%20a%20steeper%20price%20point.
LoRaWAN vs NB-IoT: A Comparison Between IoT Trend-Setters
Two of the biggest LPWAN technologies defining the future of IoT facing one another: LoRaWAN vs NB-IoT. Which one should you use for your own project?
2
odlaetet 05/08/2021 7:09 AM
yorkvillage 05/11/2021 6:02 AM
Guys, with C band on operatorâ€™s hand, will we see less small cells on the streets? Or small cell still stays relevant for dense area where higher speed and lower latency is desired.
AndersB 05/11/2021 7:13 AM
Mid Band 5G (C-Band) still have fairly small cell size compared with 5G low band. Seems like Verizon focused on High Band with femto cells and high densisity cities, T-mobile on Low band to blanket coverage all over the country and AT&T on a mix of High and Low.
yorkvillage
Guys, with C band on operatorâ€™s hand, will we see less small cells on the streets? Or small cell still stays relevant for dense area where higher speed and lower latency is desired.
Chris 05/11/2021 9:00 AM
I'm guessing we'll see a lot fewer mmWave small cells then we would have in a world where Verizon didn't win so many C-band licenses. Prior to the C-band auction, Verizon was the real leader in mmWave deployments. AT&T was reasonably far behind, and T-Mobile's deployments were a complete joke. Arguably, mmWave made more sense for Verizon than other operators since Verizon was pretty constrained in its sub-6GHz holdings. Now that Verizon's dominated the C-band auction, it's not nearly as constrained. Verizon's already making much less of a fuss about mmWave than it was several months ago. I don't think the tech is completely irrelevant though. Verizon's still adding it to new cities. While mmWave has been massively overhyped, it's a good solution for super dense areas (edited)
1
Chris
I'm guessing we'll see a lot fewer mmWave small cells then we would have in a world where Verizon didn't win so many C-band licenses. Prior to the C-band auction, Verizon was the real leader in mmWave deployments. AT&T was reasonably far behind, and T-Mobile's deployments were a complete joke. Arguably, mmWave made more sense for Verizon than other operators since Verizon was pretty constrained in its sub-6GHz holdings. Now that Verizon's dominated the C-band auction, it's not nearly as constrained. Verizon's already making much less of a fuss about mmWave than it was several months ago. I don't think the tech is completely irrelevant though. Verizon's still adding it to new cities. While mmWave has been massively overhyped, it's a good solution for super dense areas (edited)
yorkvillage 05/11/2021 2:55 PM
Thanks @Chris for your insight here. So that is actually bad news for us who like to join the build of 5G small cell network, right?
Chris
I'm guessing we'll see a lot fewer mmWave small cells then we would have in a world where Verizon didn't win so many C-band licenses. Prior to the C-band auction, Verizon was the real leader in mmWave deployments. AT&T was reasonably far behind, and T-Mobile's deployments were a complete joke. Arguably, mmWave made more sense for Verizon than other operators since Verizon was pretty constrained in its sub-6GHz holdings. Now that Verizon's dominated the C-band auction, it's not nearly as constrained. Verizon's already making much less of a fuss about mmWave than it was several months ago. I don't think the tech is completely irrelevant though. Verizon's still adding it to new cities. While mmWave has been massively overhyped, it's a good solution for super dense areas (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/11/2021 3:22 PM
when did the c-band license sale happen?
yorkvillage
Thanks @Chris for your insight here. So that is actually bad news for us who like to join the build of 5G small cell network, right?
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/11/2021 3:25 PM
bad because potentially VZW would want to offload less traffic to the CBRS options since they're less overly invested in mmWave? I guess I could see that. There's still two other MNOs and all the MVNOs that come along with it.
Steve (dewigo.com)
when did the c-band license sale happen?
yorkvillage 05/11/2021 3:28 PM
https://docs.fcc.gov/public/attachments/DOC-370267A1.pdf this February
Chris 05/11/2021 3:33 PM
Yeah, the results came out in Feb. The spectrum will gradually be cleared & put into use over the next couple years. While you could see it as bad news in some sense, I don't think it's horrible news. Verizon spent 45 billion dollars in that auction, so that's a really clear sign that the company is hungry for capacity
Steve (dewigo.com) 05/11/2021 3:33 PM
I build products for VZW and i would like to see them stop requiring mmWave modules maybe people are giving up on mmW.
Chris 05/11/2021 3:38 PM
Yeah I'm interested to see what happens with mmWave. Even if I'm not to bullish on it in the short-term, seems like it eventually could be very useful
15:40
With respect to Helium, I don't think the Verizon's mmWave strategy is all that important. Even though the helium 5G hotspots might be considered small cells, they'll still use CBRS (which is sub-6GHz 5G rather than mmWave) (edited)

(or better yet...make dynamic pricing the medium-term plan!) Trying to get a better grasp of Helium and its strategy here before I start advocating too hard though (edited)

acorn66 05/12/2021 9:34 AM
Idea for 5g. mmwave is true 5g. trees, ,people buildings , rain, moisture etc all affect. From what I've read, 200 meters is the max distance with less being better. So, instead of me having to pay for a land line internet connection (very expensive and won't give speeds needed for mmwave), what if helium and freedom fi created physical locations where your 5g device could beam directly to there gateway and they take it from there. I can see this being very limited to urban areas (neighborhoods) one to two story with the antenna being high enough and with clear los to gateway. This would become prohibitively expensive and I dont think anyone could afford. Also, who would need 2-16 gbps speeds from mmwave? Not to steam netflix or kodi . Lots of overkill. I posit this tongue and cheek. I can see why the big boys are having difficulty implementing true 5g and why they are calling enhanced 4g lte 5g. Its a marketing scam. As a Lorawan miner, i hope Helium will stay focused on implementing IO

AndersB 05/17/2021 10:18 AM
Its small cells as it's 3.55GHz--3.7GHz. Dep on the TX power, location and antenna's you will use.. I guess is prob 1/4 mile but I am not sure, a while I ago (lol, 30 years ago) I designed GSM networks which of course ~900Mhz with much better radio propagation. (edited)
Wrathed 05/17/2021 10:19 AM

10:19

AndersB 05/17/2021 10:19 AM
in 5G, CBRS is in the MidBand, the HighBand 5G which is payed spectrum (auctioned) +24GHz the range is in the femto cell level, much more limited then CBRS (edited)

Just my six senth having worked for International MNO's in the past. (edited)

The_Professional 05/18/2021 1:43 PM

The_Professional
Its not the same type of 5g. CBRS averages around 60-100 mbps. A 1 gbps line is recommended but not necessary.
pirate_rollinson 05/18/2021 6:12 PM
CBRS can raech up to 1 mile depending on the client equipment. 60-130Mbps is achievable within 0.5 mile range, but it that depends on base station / enodeB and antenna placement. It is non-line-of-sight but path loss in a cluttered environment can take that 0.5 mile to 0.25 miles. I'm interested to see what hardware choices Freedom-Fi make.
AndersB
Its small cells as it's 3.55GHz--3.7GHz. Dep on the TX power, location and antenna's you will use.. I guess is prob 1/4 mile but I am not sure, a while I ago (lol, 30 years ago) I designed GSM networks which of course ~900Mhz with much better radio propagation. (edited)
pirate_rollinson 05/18/2021 6:18 PM
If you're interested, you can find some of my reports on CBRS performance and coverage over at https://frequency.celona.io. I have made a link from as far as 4 miles with clear LoS to a Sector on a 26 storey building and using a high power CPE. Coverage to low power devices like phones is effectively 1/4 mile. In vehicle equipment with roof mount antenna will go up to 1/2 mile. CPE on a building, 1 mile.
odlaetet
Too soon....can I bet only indoor for EU?
pirate_rollinson 05/18/2021 6:19 PM
Band 42 is available for private 5G in many European countries. More will be released, the foreign regulators watched the CBRS rollout very closely.

pirate_rollinson
CBRS can raech up to 1 mile depending on the client equipment. 60-130Mbps is achievable within 0.5 mile range, but it that depends on base station / enodeB and antenna placement. acorn66 05/19/2021 6:22 AM

Bertie 05/19/2021 8:44 AM
Iâ€™m not sure I agree with the assertion thatâ€™s slow
acorn66
You state cbrs can reach speeds up to 130mbps, that seems very slow. Where did you get that info?
pirate_rollinson 05/19/2021 9:24 AM
That's CBRS TDD-LTE Config 2 which allows for more upload capacity, typically around 130 / 25 Mbps. Config 1, which @zer0tweets used in the video demo has greater download capacity but less upload. The enodeB is vonfigured to provide the preferred LTE-TDD config
The_Professional
Correct. I just dont see most people deploying larger cbrs installs. I feel that most people, who are thinking of 5g, are going to go towards the small cell you see in the demo video or Baicells 227. That will be the easiest point of entry and require the least amount of equipment. They are not going for distance. (edited)
pirate_rollinson 05/19/2021 9:28 AM
I think folks who have access to elevated locations with good 'views' for coverage might invest more but I agree, I would anticipate most people don't want to deal with the technical requirements of a full Class B installation.
Bertie
Iâ€™m not sure I agree with the assertion thatâ€™s slow
pirate_rollinson 05/19/2021 10:57 AM
Just realized I didn't answer where I got the data. I work for a startup in the CBRS space (not freeedom-fi) as tech marketing engineer. I have been testing devices and use cases on CBRS since Nov '19.

Steve (dewigo.com) 05/19/2021 12:58 PM
sounds like you have some good industry knowledge! What is your thoughts on reservations and MNO might have with partnering with a freedom fi type of system? do you think the data offload scheme proposed here is attractive to a MNO/MNVO ?
zer0tweets
hey all! a short demo of mining Helium (test net for now) using FreedomFi gateway and an indoor CBRS small cell - https://youtu.be/p2rhjeWiRK8
maco2035 ðŸ® 05/19/2021 3:03 PM
Where is the goat?
2
Steve (dewigo.com)
sounds like you have some good industry knowledge! What is your thoughts on reservations and MNO might have with partnering with a freedom fi type of system? do you think the data offload scheme proposed here is attractive to a MNO/MNVO ?
pirate_rollinson 05/19/2021 3:40 PM
Thanks Steve! The last few years have been a learning process for sure. My background was primarily WiFi and outdoor microwave, I got into CBRS because I had a specific use case in the industry I was in. As for the MNO/MVNO question.....From what I've heard, getting MNOs to sign up on a DAS install (the old/current way of building indoor cellular coverage used in stadia etc) requires a sisyphean effort. I don't think they're the market. Challenger MVNOs definitely are. However, I am more excited about the new models a network like this could support. The MVNOs who offer travel SIMs, the IoT focused MVNO opportunity. Then there's the device specific stuff, such as always-on bodycams, which become a realistic proposition with low cost, ubiquitous access.

04:46
reading this has me mind blown
04:46

NaV_CoM 05/21/2021 6:33 PM

NaV_CoM

The_Professional 05/21/2021 9:30 PM

The_Professional

odlaetet 05/22/2021 9:01 AM
How much deeper would you off load a 24byte message on a strict duty-cycle format?
odlaetet
How much deeper would you off load a 24byte message on a strict duty-cycle format?
The_Professional 05/22/2021 11:15 AM
Well there's other IOT besides Lora. When we talk about offloading 5G IOT data we're talking smart cities, cars, automation for big industrial factories like Amazon, being able to track catastrophic events. We're still in an early stages but I can tell you my company has been looking into options of what 5G offloading means. Few days ago we sat down with a possible new hire in the AI world. Lora is great for small sensor data that's going one way. This kind of IOT(5G) is real time talking back and forth. The amount of data that some of these applications that we've discussed is not going to be able to be handled by Lora. (edited)
Leo ðŸ‡¦ðŸ‡º 05/24/2021 6:12 PM
What's the current thinking around individual countries telecom regulatory regimes? Australia for example there is at least a grey area around having to have telecoms license to operate equipment that is publicly accessible. See: https://www.acma.gov.au/sites/default/files/2019-11/Carrier%20licensing%20guide.pdf â€œThe owner(s) of a network unit(s) must not allow use of their network units to provide services to the public unless they hold a carrier licence, or a nominated carrier declaration is in force over the network units or an exemption appliesâ€
michel+laszlo 05/27/2021 11:00 AM
FreedomFi's use of Magma, an open source cellular stack, along with Helium's incentive model should competitively position the partnership in what seems to be a market that's increasingly responsive to innovation and is cost-sensitive. "itâ€™s the possibility of buying 5G equipment using open-standards software that has the most potential for roiling the competitive order." https://www.wsj.com/articles/us-5g-companies-11621870061?mod=hp_jr_pos1
The U.S. Is Back in the 5G Game
The U.S. campaign against Huawei has opened the cellular-equipment market to a host of new players that previously didnâ€™t seem to have much of a chance.

The_Professional 06/04/2021 1:29 PM
Starting in September by waitlist number. Check out #freedomfi (edited)
Chris 06/04/2021 1:55 PM
Anyone thought much about how operators partnering with Helium could prevent gaming of rewards from non-genuine data use? Unlimited plans and other plans built around breakage models (i.e., plans where customers are allowed to use so much data that they become unprofitable) are so common. It would be easy for small cell owners (or their friends) to intentionally burn lots of data at their carriers' expense. (edited)
13:57
I suppose the easy approach for partner carriers would be to cap Helium-related data use at something like 5GB per month...though that could limit genuine data use too. Also, only got involved after this HIP was proposed...if this topic has already come up, let me know
Steve (dewigo.com) 06/04/2021 2:59 PM
@Chris I thought about this too. the only way to game the system is if you have a mobile data plan costing less than $.50/gb which are pretty rare in the US. So, kind of dumb unless you have some sweet mobile data arbitrage. (edited)
15:06
not to mention the costs associated with your hard line bandwidth. consumers buying unlimited plans probably come to find out its not actually unlimited. However I expect since this type of CBRS model is so fresh, bandwidth cost arbitrage is probably not high on the radar for carriers so there's probably opportunities for a garage full of raspberry pi with cell modems downloading crap 24/7 to make $.1/gb lol
Steve (dewigo.com)
@Chris I thought about this too. the only way to game the system is if you have a mobile data plan costing less than $.50/gb which are pretty rare in the US. So, kind of dumb unless you have some sweet mobile data arbitrage. (edited)
Chris 06/05/2021 11:29 AM
Huh, I guess I see this being a more common issue. If Helium were to partner with MVNOs like Mint Mobile, I'm largely on board with your points. Mint's "unlimited" plan really only includes 35GB of normal data. A few Mint subscribers might, at the end of each month, burn all their remaining data using their Helium small cells to make ~$15 bucks...but it's a hassle and not profitable enough for it to make sense to purchase plans for the exclusive purpose of gaming. A pretty big portion of US consumers (I think 100+ million) are on unlimited plans that are more-or-less-genuinely unlimited. The Big Three MNOs and their flanker brands (Visible, Cricket, Metro) have these kinds of plans.
pirate_rollinson 06/07/2021 9:04 AM
I would look beyond consumer cellular for use cases. Consumer is the most visible area of the market but the enterprise use cases are where the $$$ are at. Think of any use case where it's too costly to run your service on cellular today because of cost per Gb.
1
Chris 06/07/2021 9:08 AM
Thoughts on what those applications look like with Helium? Trying to think of what activities would appeal to enterprises where setting up a private network wouldn't be easier or more economical
pirate_rollinson 06/07/2021 12:51 PM
Agri-biz.......local co-op puts up hotspots at each farm (optional if they don't already have coverage), all farms have access to real time sensor data, private data like soil condition in their own land, publicly shared data like weather, reservoir levels etc. Logistics.....Tracking medium to high value shipments, inc accelerometer data to monitor handling issues (dropped/tipped etc) HVAC.......monitoring building systems across continental US out of band of client's own network Road monitoring Smart-city sensor data (edited)
12:52
Security - Put a presence sensor in your storage locker, boat, car, RV
12:53
Pick an industry and there's a use case
Chris 06/07/2021 1:05 PM
Hmm, I guess I'm still feeling like most of those are better suited to the LoRa network. Maybe I'm underrating how high bandwidth those sensors can be...or will become
pirate_rollinson 06/07/2021 5:37 PM
for the very low bitrate sensors LoRa is ideal. Certainly basic logisitics, asset tracking etc is a crossover area. So many requirements are hitting that include imagery.
17:39
with the advances in computer vision for classifying and understanding the visible world we're seeing imagery requirements (not talking about real time video here) pop up in unexpected places
17:42
take logistics/asset tracking......LoRa can take the positioning and acclerometer sensor data, no problem. A picture of the face of whoever opened the crate? Not as efficient.
Chris 06/07/2021 7:33 PM
gotcha, that makes sense--hadn't thought about a lot of that
pirate_rollinson 06/07/2021 8:05 PM
Then you've got enterprise data roaming, let's say I have 2000 tablets in engineer vans on the road. The Helium 5G network might be a good prime coverage option, with fallback to a major carrier network. Once coverage reaches a reasonable level I think we'll see plenty of challenger MNOs and MSPs adopting helium as a low cost option in their provider matrix.
pirate_rollinson

The Helium 5G network might be a good prime coverage option, with fallback to a major carrier network. Once coverage reaches a reasonable level I think we'll see plenty of challenger MNOs and MSPs adopting helium as a low cost option in their provider matrix.

pirate_rollinson 06/07/2021 8:19 PM

MSPs, the ability to offer a cellular package relatively easily, especially if they build out some of the infra also, same for existing regional WISP. For enterprise building their own private network, you're right, not as much appeal, but I don't think that's their goal?

Demondog 06/14/2021 12:35 PM
I have some basic questions I am hoping to get answers to. 1. Will the 5G system being proposed support voice or data alone? 2. When is it expected to be available to do internationally?
pirate_rollinson 06/14/2021 2:10 PM
1. Data only. Voice would require E911 emergency calling support. 2. When other jurisdictions open up frequency and dynamic spectrum management like the CBRS system in the USA.
14:10
...afaik
TechScaler 06/14/2021 3:08 PM
Are the SAR radiation and antenna safety issues being considered ?. Would the host of a CBRS sytem need any special insurance to cover these types of liabilities ?
pirate_rollinson 06/14/2021 3:09 PM
The power limits are much lower than the licences granted to Telcos so no special requirements for equipment that is compliant with FCC part 96 (edited)
TechScaler 06/14/2021 3:13 PM
OK thanks.. Also how would a host go about figuring out the number of antennas, location, height and power settings etc..
TechScaler 06/14/2021 3:26 PM

Today if you take an AT&T phone and roam in Mexico, it gets itemized as a roaming charge on your monthly bill. With Helium CBRS Data Credits, who pays the Data Credits charges for CBRS service inside a building ? The carrier or the consumer ?.
pirate_rollinson
1. Data only. Voice would require E911 emergency calling support. 2. When other jurisdictions open up frequency and dynamic spectrum management like the CBRS system in the USA.

Demondog
On point 1. Are you saying it cannot support the E911? On point 2. Say someone was willing to get a full license is it possible then outside some form of CBRS program?
pirate_rollinson 06/14/2021 3:55 PM
1. Yes, the technical demands required for e911 support would represent too great a barrier to entry for hosts. That would go against the goals of the Helium network. 2. Anyone with FCC compliant outdoor CBRS hardware can operate a network.
pirate_rollinson
1. Yes, the technical demands required for e911 support would represent too great a barrier to entry for hosts. That would go against the goals of the Helium network. 2. Anyone with FCC compliant outdoor CBRS hardware can operate a network.
Demondog 06/14/2021 3:57 PM

pirate_rollinson 06/14/2021 3:58 PM
OTT voice will be supported. Some handsets with carrier WiFi calling enabled and an active data connection (CBRS in this case) will use that for calls in the absence of any other coverage.
Demondog 06/14/2021 4:00 PM

Demondog
So what data speed will the 5G support.
pirate_rollinson 06/14/2021 4:00 PM
currently, CBRS small cell radios are LTE only. Depending on the Carrier Aggregation capabilities of the radios they recommend, anything from 180/15 to 400/100. It remains to be seen and freedom-fi have specifically stated they will announce comparible radios in future, until then...cool your jets folks.

Anthonyra 06/21/2021 7:46 AM
To max out the Data Credits overage 32% (meaning DC to HNT burn equilibrium has been reached) it would only require 36 Terabytes of data to be moved with CBRS which isn't a lot of data when talking about scale. A town of 36k people watching atleast 1 hour of Netflix each would accomplish that. Edit: It'd need to be a constant use of 72k people watching Netflix to max out the DC to HNT per epoch since epochs are 30 mins. (edited)

Wick BOT 06/22/2021 4:46 PM
dank7452 has been silenced for 1m Reason: Posting NSFW Websites
dank7452#2698 | 573196868171857921
zer0tweets 06/22/2021 5:34 PM
@Steve (dewigo.com) I can probably share a few specifics without naming names for offload partners
17:34
we have a fairly long list of early conversations, but there are 3 offload candidates in active work stages
17:35
2 of them are full MNOs with their subscribers. One of them is a Tier 1 in the US.
17:35
3rd is an MVNO that mostly sells prepaid data plans aimed at eSIM enabled phones
17:36
the offload integration is done via a roaming relationship, i.e. their network core is integrated with Magma, which is used as the network core for the Helium cellular network
17:39
to the question above about buying HNT etc.... that part is completely abstracted away from the MNO/MVNO... HNT to DC conversion is done by us behind the scenes
17:40
on the HIP 27 next steps... we've been working on a next iteration of it, re-introducing the proof-of-coverage for cellular concept; that was a discussion we had initially in the recording above which fell a bit short first time around primarily due to concerns over how hack proof it can be
17:41
we think we have a new, safer and better approach to have cellular PoC on the Helium network which I think we should be able to throw out for a broader discussion
4

Thank you for the progress update @zer0tweets, exciting stuff.

to the question above about buying HNT etc.... that part is completely abstracted away from the MNO/MVNO... HNT to DC conversion is done by us behind the scenes

15:23

Steve (dewigo.com)
And if there is a reason why PoC needs to be there, why cant we just fall back on 915Mhz as the PoC frequency for all wireless technologies?
zer0tweets 06/23/2021 3:23 PM
because you cannot proof coverage of 5G by broadcasting 915Mhz Lora signal
15:23
just because you have Lora up doesn't mean you have a CBRS cell up
Steve (dewigo.com) 06/23/2021 3:23 PM
but the proof is in the pudding $$
15:24
I guess it depends on how lucrative PoC is expected to be for CBRS hosts. if its still a source of income, people will ask for it
zer0tweets 06/23/2021 3:24 PM
we need to be able to verify that the CBRS cell is up and reliably broadcasting signal to steer a phone connection to it
15:24
otherwise we'll be steering connections to cells that don't exist and that will be the end of operators offloading anything
Steve (dewigo.com) 06/23/2021 3:26 PM
I can see what you mean..if I'm an MNO, i'd be suspect of cells popping up which I dont own, which also dont have an oversight mechanism to show they are providing decent coverage
15:26
But it begs the question, does an MNO care about PoC? or do they not know enough to care yet?
15:30
Or, instead PoC forms an integral part of how Freedomfi does back end routing in the software management dashboard thingy..
TechScaler 06/23/2021 3:52 PM
Showing network coverage at a location is a strategic competitive advantage to a carrier.. MNOs get measured by %age of people and regions that they cover. Having a blockchain based PoC will certainly mean a lot to a MNO/MVNO
15:53
CBRS helps carriers fill the holes in network coverage

pirate_rollinson 06/24/2021 8:51 AM
I suspect PoC will use the spectrum grants that are issued to radios by the Spectrum Access Servers, which has to have accurate lat/long and mount height included. Combining that data with information from the RAN like neighbour relation table might be the route they take. There's plenty of data available from the magma core, just depends what they choose to integrate with the blockchain.
BruSkies 06/25/2021 4:44 AM
I used to verify and troubleshoot 3G towers a long time ago, so things may have changed, but the cell would handshake to another tower based on the signal strength of tower A being better than the old tower B connection, so while I'm sure they still want accurate location information the phones themselves are usually pretty good at decision making
04:45
except in the case of where a tower has a slow backhaul, because it doesn't really check overall download speeds =/

Automatic Neighbour Relation (ANR) | 4G 5G World
Manually provisioning and managing neighbor cells in traditional mobile network is challenging task and it becomes more difficult as new mobile technologies are being rolled out while 2G/3G cells a

dm76 06/27/2021 6:25 AM
Interesting- does this mean there will be HNT rewards based on PoC? It's the model that made Helium so attractive in the first place. Seems pretty obvious that providing an incentive to build out the network would make partnering with us an easier sell to carriers, especially since the equipment is more expensive.
Anthonyra 06/27/2021 6:31 AM
I still don't like providing PoC for CBRS because the rewards need to come from somewhere. And for the fact that it'll be only US based stealing those rewards from the overall pool wouldn't be fair to the rest of the world. The partnerships should be the incentive to build anyways. In the current model they couldn't rely on a partner company to provide use so instead they opted to incentives growth so that "if you build it they will come" to take affect.
1
dm76 06/27/2021 8:15 AM
Agree that an incentive comes from the partnership but even then where is the incentive to host a CBRS hotspot unless you're in an area with really heavy traffic? Even then with the .50/GB rate the ROI is low, and in many cases you may never hit break even. The scenarios I'm envisioning are small towns and suburbs where it would be great for a carrier to be able to advertise 5G coverage, but the ROI for an individual hotspot owner would be negligible.
08:16
Totally understand your concerns as well of course - I wonder if there have been any discussions about forking this into a completely separate project?

Anthonyra

And for the fact that it'll be only US based stealing those rewards from the overall pool wouldn't be fair to the rest of the world. The partnerships should be the incentive to build anyways. Chris 06/28/2021 9:12 AM
Hmm, I'm on the other side of this (though I'll admit everything is uncertain until we know what sort of deals are struck with carriers). If Helium doesn't do PoC for 5G, the only thing that gets incentivized in the short term is building out little islands of coverage in super dense areas. At ~$0.50 per GB, areas need to be awfully dense before returns are particularly good. With LoRaWAN, Helium was happy to massively subsidize network building (i.e., giving people lots of HNT via PoC rewards--even though almost no data was sent over the network). If there's not a similar subsidy with 5G, the rollout of the tech might be awfully slow (edited)
Chris
Hmm, I'm on the other side of this (though I'll admit everything is uncertain until we know what sort of deals are struck with carriers). If Helium doesn't do PoC for 5G, the only thing that gets incentivized in the short term is building out little islands of coverage in super dense areas. At ~$0.50 per GB, areas need to be awfully dense before returns are particularly good. With LoRaWAN, Helium was happy to massively subsidize network building (i.e., giving people lots of HNT via PoC rewards--even though almost no data was sent over the network). If there's not a similar subsidy with 5G, the rollout of the tech might be awfully slow (edited)
Anthonyra 06/28/2021 9:18 AM
So back to my original point, where do these PoC rewards come from? If you take them from PoC then 1 country out of the 89 that currently support Helium will be eligible for those rewards. I don't think that is fair.. If you really want PoC I guess the 0.95% from challenge creation would be open once validators take that over.
Chris 06/28/2021 9:18 AM
I'd say take it from the existing PoC pool
Anthonyra 06/28/2021 9:19 AM
Yea, try talking those other 88 countries into that...
Chris 06/28/2021 9:22 AM
There would have to be careful thought to decide how much of the PoC rewards are available for 5G-related stuff. While the USA is only 1 country of ~100 (and 5G is only one of the two technologies Helium will offer in the US), I think it's pretty clear that succeeding in 5G would be enormously valuable to Helium. I'd like to see HNT incentives set to match the opportunity (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 06/28/2021 9:23 AM
As long as CBRS PoC rewards aren't weighted unfairly, i don't see an issue (I am american). Just buy and deploy more LoRa units. There's really nothing rate limiting the PoC availability between CBRS and LoRa
2
Chris 06/28/2021 9:24 AM
Putting this all much more simply, Helium was willing to reward a huge portion of the project's value (as of today, worth the better part of a billion dollars) to get LoRaWAN off the ground even though there's still approximately $0 worth of data going over that network. If it was worth subsidizing LoRaWAN a ton, it seems odd to me that 5G shouldn't be subsidized at all
09:25
Of course, there are some dis-analogies. The business models are different between the technologies, Helium's more mature now, etc. But if there's no willingness to subsidize new tech within the Helium project, @dm76's point about the value of a fork starts making a lot of sense (edited)
Steve (dewigo.com) 06/28/2021 9:28 AM
From another perspective, one of the best thing Helium could do for early adopters is insentivise 5G deployment bigly. To Chris's point, the data credit consumption is pretty abysmal in LoRa space, which extrapolated over years is pretty bad for return. 5G places a big demand on DCs contrary to LoRa. Someone should do the math for DC demand created for a single 5g spot versus Lora (one 5G to 100s-1000s of LoRa?)
Steve (dewigo.com)
As long as CBRS PoC rewards aren't weighted unfairly, i don't see an issue (I am american). Just buy and deploy more LoRa units. There's really nothing rate limiting the PoC availability between CBRS and LoRa
Anthonyra 06/28/2021 9:28 AM
I'm an American too and there's no % that would be fair since the other countries literally can't even participate to try and claim those rewards. If you have 6% to this new PoC 1/5 of the current allocation without DC overage you're looking at 100 HNT an epoch going to just US hotspots. Factor in the realization that current PoC isn't spoof proof you now opened up a completely new vector for gaming that will directly reduce the overall rewards from the rest of the network. If the network isn't need in a farm then it shouldn't built there. If it's only needed to offload in dense areas than DC should do quite nicely to incentive that. Especially when you reach 36TB per epoch of data usage and the PoC rewards across the network drops by 1/3 due to no more DC overage (edited)
Anthonyra

Steve (dewigo.com) 06/28/2021 9:32 AM

Anthonyra 06/28/2021 9:34 AM

Chris 06/28/2021 9:35 AM

Anthonyra 06/28/2021 9:37 AM
I can see issues from previous network history but if the community decides that PoC is needed for 5G well than I guess I'll be going after a piece of that pie
Chris 06/28/2021 9:44 AM
Yeah, definitely some tough governance questions to navigate. One last thought: even if you can't personally participate in offering 5G coverage, it may still be in your interest for 5G to be subsidized to a degree. I.e., if 5G significantly pushes up the dollar value of HNT, that could more than offset whatever LoRa miners lose in nominal PoC rewards.
Anthonyra 06/28/2021 9:49 AM
I think the actual DC usage will drive up that side of the equation. It would only take a city of 72,000 people watching 0.5 hour (aligned with an epoch) of Netflix for the network to hit the DC-HNT burn equilibrium ... That's one decent size city in the US. Once that equilibrium hits anything above that is the flywheel in overdrive... Just one city would cause that with 5G. Edit: To be based on a epoch (edited)
1
Steve (dewigo.com) 06/28/2021 9:50 AM
another point is a decent 5G deployment will be about 10x more expensive and time consuming to complete than the equivalent LoRa. that needs a commensurate reward or at least a less volatile and more predictable reward trajectory.

Chris 06/28/2021 10:04 AM
So I think your comment may get at the heart of what I'm saying. If 5G could generate such value (e.g., pushing "the network to meet the DC-HNT burn equilibrium"), that's incredibly valuable for HNT holders. I'm merely suggesting letting the people offering 5G coverage capture a bit of that value (rather than just getting compensated for data transfer)
10:05
The idea here is not so much about fairness as setting up a win-win situation for both 5G providers and HNT holders.
10:08
@Tushar, seems like you've thought hard about the economics and incentives underlying Helium. Do you know if there's any precedent for utility tokens with multiple uses? I'm trying to get a better grasp of governance issues & economic phenomena and that could arise because Helium uses a single token for multiple wireless technologies (edited)
Tushar 06/28/2021 10:09 AM
IMO it is the same use, not multiple uses. depends on the way you look at it i guess. I see it like this: (edited)
10:09
Data Credits are used to pay for data transfer
10:09
the first network was lorawan. the second will be 5G. but we are not going to stop there
10:09
we could add wifi, 4G, 3G, or even satellite backhaul
10:10
HIP 27 defines the way the blockchain can price data transfer on all of these networks
Chris 06/28/2021 10:24 AM
Gotcha. I'm mostly thinking through how non-DC rewards should be handled as more technologies are added. Arguably, one of PoC's main functions early on is subsidizing the first users of a technology. Since we're in a domain with huge network effects, subsidies for early adopters are a good idea. Figuring out how to optimize the size of early subsidies for each technology feels important
10:26
Might eventually try to collect these thoughts more coherently in a blog post
TechScaler 06/28/2021 2:56 PM
In addition to the one time setup costs Are we factoring in cost of maintaining the network and back hauling the data ?. I would think a CBRS system will need a fiber backhaul. I am not sure what a fiber backhaul for a commercial CBRS deployment would cost.. any ideas ?
14:59

TechScaler

The_Professional 06/28/2021 3:13 PM
The max is downlink the CBRs is 150mbps. You can have multiple radios on a 500gb line. This does very on location but a 500 gigabyte line should cost you about $150(that's what I'm currently paying for the office). You can technically run it off of a HughesNet. Starlink will be a good option for remote locations. See my pinned message in the Freedomfi channel for more monthly fees. (edited)
1

This does very on location but a 500 gigabyte line should cost you about $150(that's what I'm currently paying for the office). You can technically run it off of a HughesNet. Starlink will be a good option for remote locations. See my pinned message in the Freedomfi channel for more monthly fees. (edited)

pirate_rollinson 07/05/2021 2:17 AM
I would say the chances are slim to non existent. Running a mobile core is very different to Lora, even with all the blockchain processing power in an OG hotspot. I don't know what hardware is in Freedom-Fi's gateway but my lab systems require i7 multi core and 32gb ram to run an LTE CBRS mobile core.

Chris 07/09/2021 10:11 AM
I'm going to continue my shtick of shouting for dynamic, market-based pricing
Chris
I'm going to continue my shtick of shouting for dynamic, market-based pricing
Steve (dewigo.com) 07/09/2021 10:13 AM
+1 pricing is really the crux of HIP27 part II (or part III, if @zer0tweets makes part II focus on 5G PoC). A dynamic or at least smart pricing model needs to be folded in for all data transfer types, so far the can has been kicked down the road. Maybe we could look to industries like utilities or insurance for direction? (edited)
Tushar 07/09/2021 1:37 PM
Dynamic pricing introduces a lot of risk for the end users of the network because they donâ€™t know how much they will pay. Very scary imo
13:38
Maybe it could work if the price can only update after some time so end users have stability. Or the price is locked within some bounds
Chris 07/09/2021 1:42 PM
I agree the fear aspect is a major downside. And dynamic pricing probably makes more sense as a medium term plan (once congestion is an actual problem) rather than something to be implemented immediately
13:45
While dynamic pricing would introduce a lot of complexity (and possibly fear), it has the potential to be one of the biggest economic innovations in the history of wireless...and Helium might be in a better position to drive it forward than anyone has ever been
13:50
With Helium's current CBRS plans, the fear might not actually be that hard to navigate. Helium could initially throw some kind of floor and ceiling on the cost per GB to prevent carriers & small cell hosts from getting scared away. After some time, people will see how the market functions, then likely become a lot more comfortable with the idea of removing price floors & ceilings. (edited)
13:55
It might be particularly easy if, a few years down the road, Helium CBRS is still just used for offloading large companies' traffic. For companies operating at scale, software could handle decision making as prices shift. Big carriers also have a lot of familiarity with these sort of pricing questions thanks to experience with roaming policies
Chris 07/09/2021 2:02 PM
Tangentially related, Peter Adderton, the guy originally behind Boost Mobile, is in the process of launching a cellular carrier that looks like it may try to take advantage of efficiencies of dynamic pricing while limiting complexity and risk for end customers. Not a ton of details are in the open yet, but it'll be interesting to see how that business model shakes out
Chris
Tangentially related, Peter Adderton, the guy originally behind Boost Mobile, is in the process of launching a cellular carrier that looks like it may try to take advantage of efficiencies of dynamic pricing while limiting complexity and risk for end customers. Not a ton of details are in the open yet, but it'll be interesting to see how that business model shakes out

Tushar

stak_at 07/09/2021 7:29 PM
you say risk i say friction ... the lora side is fixed ... this seems like an equalizer if you can keep it economical across markets.
stak_at
you say risk i say friction ... the lora side is fixed ... this seems like an equalizer if you can keep it economical across markets.
Chris 07/10/2021 1:09 PM
I think either word is accurate. Scary seems accurate if network users are uncertain whether they'll spend $0.20/GB or $20/GB for any period of data use. The big question is whether network users could turn fear into mere friction with software to throttle (or otherwise limit) data use when prices are too high (edited)
Chris 07/10/2021 1:20 PM
FWIW, my toy model for thinking about the importance of dynamic pricing: Scenario A: An MNO has a slightly congested network and can only offer data speeds of ~10Mbps to each user Scenario B: An MNO is super congested and users can only get sub-1Mbps speeds In Scenario A, I don't see an MNO being willing to spend even $0.50/GB. In Scenario B, I can easily see MNOs paying $5+/GB
1
The_Professional 07/11/2021 3:21 PM
How I look at it. Hypothetically, It will cost a MNO 10 million dollars to cover a city in 5g. That gives them 75% coverage. For them to get the other 25% it may cost them 60 million. Its not worth the extra 25%. Other tower companies come in and build out covering an additional 15%. We get to come in to help fill in the rest. Tower companies have started already: https://www.americantower.com/us/news-and-events/blog/5g-buildings-and-venues.html (edited)
The 5G Opportunity in Buildings and Venues
5G brings important new opportunities for building and venue owners to enhance the user experience, meet demands, and drive revenue.

AS 07/17/2021 12:14 PM
Couldnâ€™t this be solved with a swap or futures contract or other similar derivative. The end user wouldnâ€™t want the price volatility but would be willing to pay a slight premium for a predictable price. And a third party would buy and aggregate the volatility risk at a market price and pool/diversify any idiosyncratic elements. It doesnâ€™t have to be Helium providing the floor/ceiling â€” anyone could. And blockchain-based systems of 100% digital assets make it much easier to do this in real-time than sayâ€¦physically settled barrels of oil that will literally end up on your doorstep if you donâ€™t sell out of the contract.
Tushar 07/17/2021 12:58 PM
Thatâ€™s an interesting idea
12:59
Seems like it would work but then someone needs to build the derivatives market and operate it
12:59
Not trivial to do
AS
Couldnâ€™t this be solved with a swap or futures contract or other similar derivative. The end user wouldnâ€™t want the price volatility but would be willing to pay a slight premium for a predictable price. And a third party would buy and aggregate the volatility risk at a market price and pool/diversify any idiosyncratic elements. It doesnâ€™t have to be Helium providing the floor/ceiling â€” anyone could. And blockchain-based systems of 100% digital assets make it much easier to do this in real-time than sayâ€¦physically settled barrels of oil that will literally end up on your doorstep if you donâ€™t sell out of the contract.
Chris 07/18/2021 6:44 AM
Seems like this should be possible. In the short-term, where Helium 5G is only used by wireless carriers, it may not even be necessary--without building anything new carriers could spread the price risk across a large customer base. Could be a great idea though if end users ever connect directly to Helium 5G. You'd likely get some adverse selection (people who are unusually likely to run into congestion would be more willing to pay a premium for fixed-price data), but it'd probably be manageable
Aloha 1 07/18/2021 2:03 PM
Major companies are start involving home internet now with 5G. (edited)

zer0tweets 07/22/2021 11:39 AM
hey all; first of all apologies for the silence... per the comments that many of you made above, it is indeed, because we are working hard on delivering towards September ship date. special thanks for @The_Professional @pirate_rollinson @Steve (dewigo.com) and others for doing an amazing job correctly fielding 90% of the questions in here... you guys are amazing
2
11:39
we will be at the next community meeting next Wednesday and will provide some updates then; feel free to join live or watch the recording later
4
2
11:40
we'll also throw in a google doc or an etherpad in here, for all to post questions you want us to address during the community meeting so we can make those pointed
2
11:46
a few high level updates: 1) we are still tracking towards September ship date... likely mid-end september; 2) the september batch will limited 500-1000 units most likely and we'll make those available to waitlist reservation holders 3) we will honor our commitments re: satisfying all of waitlist holders by Q1 2022 (and if stars align even prior to year end) and have secured manufacturing capacity to accomplish that despite semiconductor shortages etc. 4) we are still continuing our work with the pipeline of MNOs and MVNOs for offload; as expected that's the most challenging and slow moving part, but we are pushing through it; 5) we are working on an update to HIP27 that we expect to discuss at the community meeting this coming Wednesday that re-introduces PoC for 5G/LTE/Wi-Fi and addresses some of the hackability concerns that the community expressed when we first discussed it back in the spring
4

Aloha 1 07/22/2021 2:57 PM
Thank you for your update. Please do not cutoff at 500 for the 1st batch.
1
AS
Couldnâ€™t this be solved with a swap or futures contract or other similar derivative. The end user wouldnâ€™t want the price volatility but would be willing to pay a slight premium for a predictable price. And a third party would buy and aggregate the volatility risk at a market price and pool/diversify any idiosyncratic elements. It doesnâ€™t have to be Helium providing the floor/ceiling â€” anyone could. And blockchain-based systems of 100% digital assets make it much easier to do this in real-time than sayâ€¦physically settled barrels of oil that will literally end up on your doorstep if you donâ€™t sell out of the contract.
lysanderG 07/22/2021 7:36 PM
Yes, this "fixed vs floating" transaction is the very definition of a swap. To price a swap, however, you need some sort of future price curve (basically the price of the futures). Interest rates, oil, nat gas, etc. have deep, liquid futures markets allowing for market/transparent pricing. No such futures market exists for 5G data, though (as @Tushar pointed out). Not yet anyway. Helium's model/platform, though, changes all of that, IMO. For the first time ever, a market based price for moving data is available. I suspect it won't be too long before futures pricing of data (ie, HNT) is a thing.
zer0tweets
a few high level updates: 1) we are still tracking towards September ship date... likely mid-end september; 2) the september batch will limited 500-1000 units most likely and we'll make those available to waitlist reservation holders 3) we will honor our commitments re: satisfying all of waitlist holders by Q1 2022 (and if stars align even prior to year end) and have secured manufacturing capacity to accomplish that despite semiconductor shortages etc. 4) we are still continuing our work with the pipeline of MNOs and MVNOs for offload; as expected that's the most challenging and slow moving part, but we are pushing through it; 5) we are working on an update to HIP27 that we expect to discuss at the community meeting this coming Wednesday that re-introduces PoC for 5G/LTE/Wi-Fi and addresses some of the hackability concerns that the community expressed when we first discussed it back in the spring
Gable 07/23/2021 6:39 AM

Gable
any idea about an EU product? or it's going to be US only for the foreseeable future?
zer0tweets 07/23/2021 8:27 AM
yes, we plan to roll out EU focusing on Wi-Fi offload vs. CBRS Q1 next year

zer0tweets
a few high level updates: 1) we are still tracking towards September ship date... likely mid-end september; 2) the september batch will limited 500-1000 units most likely and we'll make those available to waitlist reservation holders 3) we will honor our commitments re: satisfying all of waitlist holders by Q1 2022 (and if stars align even prior to year end) and have secured manufacturing capacity to accomplish that despite semiconductor shortages etc. 4) we are still continuing our work with the pipeline of MNOs and MVNOs for offload; as expected that's the most challenging and slow moving part, but we are pushing through it; 5) we are working on an update to HIP27 that we expect to discuss at the community meeting this coming Wednesday that re-introduces PoC for 5G/LTE/Wi-Fi and addresses some of the hackability concerns that the community expressed when we first discussed it back in the spring

Helium5G - FreedomFi
Earn HNT cryptocurrency by providing 5G cellular coverage. FreedomFi Gateways will soon become compatible with the Helium blockchain, making it possible for hosts to earn HNT cryptocurrency by offloading carrier cellular networks using 5G and, later, Wi-Fi hotspots. ferebee pinned a message to this channel. 07/26/2021 12:02 PM
Steve (dewigo.com)
+1 pricing is really the crux of HIP27 part II (or part III, if @zer0tweets makes part II focus on 5G PoC). A dynamic or at least smart pricing model needs to be folded in for all data transfer types, so far the can has been kicked down the road. Maybe we could look to industries like utilities or insurance for direction? (edited)
ferebee 07/26/2021 12:36 PM
I donâ€™t get the idea of dynamic pricing. A major advantage of Helium to date has been the 10x to 100x advantage in capital efficiency vs. incumbent telcos. That should be enough to cover the 10x price advantage implied in the proposed $0.50/GB rate for 5G for good locations. As technology progresses, the price efficiency gap should widen, if anything, bringing additional small-cell locations within range of profitability. For a new entrant like Helium to succeed, a simple, low price is essential as @Tushar says. Incumbents donâ€™t have a lot of high-powered procurement cycles to spend on an offering that will start off at low volume. It has to be simple.
2

The_Professional 07/27/2021 10:05 AM
Thank you for question 20!
ferebee
I donâ€™t get the idea of dynamic pricing. A major advantage of Helium to date has been the 10x to 100x advantage in capital efficiency vs. incumbent telcos. That should be enough to cover the 10x price advantage implied in the proposed $0.50/GB rate for 5G for good locations. As technology progresses, the price efficiency gap should widen, if anything, bringing additional small-cell locations within range of profitability. For a new entrant like Helium to succeed, a simple, low price is essential as @Tushar says. Incumbents donâ€™t have a lot of high-powered procurement cycles to spend on an offering that will start off at low volume. It has to be simple.
Chris 07/27/2021 10:17 AM
So my major qualm here is that I don't think Helium can actually offer a 10x pricing advantage in most cases.
10:21
Most of the time, the marginal cost an MNO (e.g., Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T) pays to move a GB of data is very close to $0. While an extra GB of bandwidth is usually worth ~$0 to an MNO, that bandwidth might be worth many dollars per GB during periods of network congestion.
10:22
My impression is that Helium's primary goal with 5G is to get MNOs as customers. IMO, dynamic pricing is a much better fit in that case. Especially if Helium 5G continues to be about creating supplemental capacity rather than supplemental coverage.
10:27
Something like the 10X cost savings idea could hold for MVNOs that piggyback on other networks (MVNOs are used by a minority of people in the US--very roughly ballpark at like 10% of cell phone lines). $0.50/GB would generally lead to big big savings for MVNOs (though my gut is closer to 5x savings than 10x).
Chris
Most of the time, the marginal cost an MNO (e.g., Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T) pays to move a GB of data is very close to $0. While an extra GB of bandwidth is usually worth ~$0 to an MNO, that bandwidth might be worth many dollars per GB during periods of network congestion.
ferebee 07/27/2021 3:39 PM
My understanding is that the rate the MNOs pay neutral hosts such as Boingo was $5/GB not long ago. Do you have current data? The point is not the cost of Helium bandwidth vs. marginal MNO bandwidth over existing infrastructure. The point is Helium bandwidth vs. the cost to MNOs to install new cells in locations such as indoor venues, where the Helium 10â€“100x capital efficiency advantage of installation is applicable. MNOs will need to provide 5G coverage in indoor and other difficult locations, in order to remain competitive, that currently donâ€™t have 5G. Speculatively, similar mechanisms may apply in the future to millimeter wave installations, which require an inordinate number of small cells vs. legacy networks.
2
1

The point is Helium bandwidth vs. the cost to MNOs to install new cells in locations such as indoor venues, where the Helium 10â€“100x capital efficiency advantage of installation is applicable. MNOs will need to provide 5G coverage in indoor and other difficult locations, in order to remain competitive, that currently donâ€™t have 5G. Speculatively, similar mechanisms may apply in the future to millimeter wave installations, which require an inordinate number of small cells vs. legacy networks.

My feeling here is that Helium is more going to be an alternative/supplement to MNOs macro cells rather than an alternative to other neutral hosts. If I'm wrong about that, then I have a serious misunderstanding here (edited)

Chris 07/28/2021 12:03 PM

12:04

BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 07/28/2021 12:07 PM
My point of view, your're asking to take away from witnessing on lorawan to grow 5g, on a hotspot that has lorawan, why not confirm the coverage with the ecc from the lorawan part? why do they need to earn from both? you're also asking us to kill growth of lorawan to bring up 5g. The point of PoC was because the data wasn't there and needed coverage, a chicken and the egg situation. But in this case, the devices are already in the wild in number, why do they need to earn to put 5g hotspots live when they turn them on and have an instant earnings from data?
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io
My point of view, your're asking to take away from witnessing on lorawan to grow 5g, on a hotspot that has lorawan, why not confirm the coverage with the ecc from the lorawan part? why do they need to earn from both? you're also asking us to kill growth of lorawan to bring up 5g. The point of PoC was because the data wasn't there and needed coverage, a chicken and the egg situation. But in this case, the devices are already in the wild in number, why do they need to earn to put 5g hotspots live when they turn them on and have an instant earnings from data?
Chris 07/28/2021 12:14 PM
I don't think using LoRa to confirm 5G coverage would be robust. It'd likely be game-able and 5G propagates differently. While I don't think the chicken and egg problem is as severe with 5G, it's still there. There's going to be a lot of complexity involved in carriers building systems for offloading to Helium's 5G. Much easier to get carriers on board if Helium has a large enough network to justify the hassle
Chris
I don't think using LoRa to confirm 5G coverage would be robust. It'd likely be game-able and 5G propagates differently. While I don't think the chicken and egg problem is as severe with 5G, it's still there. There's going to be a lot of complexity involved in carriers building systems for offloading to Helium's 5G. Much easier to get carriers on board if Helium has a large enough network to justify the hassle

Does PoC mean do I need multiple 5G gateway around mine? What happen if I am the only one?
pirate_rollinson 07/28/2021 2:14 PM
No. The proposal is to use iOS devices with an eSim profile that could passively or actively witness the 5G network. Note, the early deployments are not 5G, they will use LTE B48 CBRS indoor small cells.
2
TechScaler
Exactly my thought.. Perhaps the reciever can be built into the gateway itself ?.
Chris 07/28/2021 2:19 PM
Would probably be costly & take a design change. Also, these 5G cells won't broadcast nearly as far as LoRa, so lone wolf small cells would be extremely common. Using handsets is likely a lot better.
TechScaler 07/28/2021 2:30 PM
I guess a host should bundle the cost of a couple of smartphones along with Gateway and Small cell.. For example if installed in a food court, one of these smartphones will have to be at a nearby restaurant

just makes remote management even more challenging

BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 07/28/2021 3:28 PM

Lorawan exists mostly everywhere, 5g spectrum in one country could cost $100m+. If a lorawan host wants to increase usage they can spent $200 on sensors to do so in his neighbourhood, 5g he can't do that without spending £10k and have land for a tower. There's no proffit in home installations for the average person, and your asking them to earn less so their hnt could be worth more eventually. The money sounds to me better spent on promoting Lorawan usage (edited)

JMF 07/28/2021 6:13 PM
A couple points to the above: @ChiefGolan Tushar was on the no POC train when I first started discussing this with him, so he's a convert. I'm sure he still believes that 5G has a lot of potential either way, but it's a matter of de-risking the rollout and giving us better odds. But, I also agree with @Steve (dewigo.com) . Coverage is different for CBRS. It doesn't need to be be contiguous like like Lorawan, but there does need to be enough high value coverage to attract customers (carriers) to the network. Each unit may have mutually exclusive value, but a $100 bn company is only going to be interested in something that fills in enough of their gaps to add measurable value. BUT once those deals are in place, new gateway owners are walking into a multitude of massive contracts. Those multi carrier deals are the biggest barrier of entry for new competitors or 5G gateway groups from splitting off.
1
JMF
A couple points to the above: @ChiefGolan Tushar was on the no POC train when I first started discussing this with him, so he's a convert. I'm sure he still believes that 5G has a lot of potential either way, but it's a matter of de-risking the rollout and giving us better odds. But, I also agree with @Steve (dewigo.com) . Coverage is different for CBRS. It doesn't need to be be contiguous like like Lorawan, but there does need to be enough high value coverage to attract customers (carriers) to the network. Each unit may have mutually exclusive value, but a $100 bn company is only going to be interested in something that fills in enough of their gaps to add measurable value. BUT once those deals are in place, new gateway owners are walking into a multitude of massive contracts. Those multi carrier deals are the biggest barrier of entry for new competitors or 5G gateway groups from splitting off.

I'm saying if 5g is so data hungry and the devices already exist why does it need PoC, you won't exactly put an indoor cell where 5g wouldn't be used, and don't the freedom fi gateways come with lorawan? Are you telling me you can't place a 5g antenna indoors and run a lorawan antenna outside? If you can't the lorawan part is useless.

Anthonyra 07/29/2021 5:33 AM
Iâ€™d be okay with PoC rewards if and only if it works as the DC overage as of today. The PoC is the remainder of whatâ€™s left from DC rewards. If 5G is being built out and current DC usage remains the same than they get 30% of the overall rewards for PoC however if BME is met (which means a butt ton of data is being moved via 5G) they will get 0% PoC but over ~90% of the DC rewards pot still but in the form of data transfer. PoC should go to the most under utilized wireless protocol in regards to DC spent which could occur on the 2nd halving. (edited)
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io

We have no route to market for 5g, it's not a level playing field, that is my consern. I'm saying if 5g is so data hungry and the devices already exist why does it need PoC, you won't exactly put an indoor cell where 5g wouldn't be used, and don't the freedom fi gateways come with lorawan? Steve (dewigo.com) 07/29/2021 9:16 AM
I think PoC is necessary for 5g because of the increased risk in deployment. Risk comes in the form of: higher up front costs and unknown status of offload partners. I really doubt AT&T and T-Mobile are going to jump on board from day one, meaning the node is serving a very small cross section of users. Data throughput may be much smaller than you expect. PoC will juice the buildout, increasing likelihood of a big MNO partner. Its a similar chicken and egg problem as LoRa: the network must be big before people jump in with both feet. Regarding the US exclusivity, this is a moot point and IMO has no bearing on the HIP. Additional point, LoRa PoC comes for free because the hardware is cheap. It should earn PoC from both. (edited)
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 07/29/2021 9:20 AM
No one can explain to me why freedomfi's gateways come with lorawan gateways, that's double PoC isn't it? Wouldn't they be able to earn there to support the 5g?
Steve (dewigo.com) 07/29/2021 9:20 AM
Why shouldn't we explore new PoC methods? I personally think the eSim idea is really innovative and could have some unexpected benefits.
BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 07/29/2021 9:20 AM
You need PoC for coverage, but we don't pay mappers to map coverage for lorawan
JMF 07/29/2021 9:21 AM

BFGNeil - Trackpac.io

Steve (dewigo.com) 07/29/2021 9:22 AM
the HW costs like $20. Its piggybacking on the existing HW. The FFi gateway costs similar as other vendors (less than some even, which is hilarious). It may be double the PoC but the two methods of PoC will be completely different with different antenna setup, different deploy strategy, different wiring and mounting needs..

Anthonyra 07/29/2021 9:31 AM
If the PoC reward for 5G was based only on the overage of the DC reward pool I'd be down.. once the BME is met than no PoC would be rewarded towards 5g because the data moved to those gateways would make up for no PoC
JMF 07/29/2021 9:31 AM
A couple massive points: 1) The carrier deals are going to be paramount to the CBRS wireless networks success and it's absolutely going to take time to build using data from the network. I am not in those discussions but I believe MOST CBRS units will not have access to roaming deals in their locations immediately or possibly for awhile, until one of the big 3 are signed up. So without any PoC, there will be literally 0 earnings on those units. 2) Yes we have mappers for Lorawan, but it's a relatively small number and the scale of what would be required for 5G is a magnitude or two bigger. It's worth remember that you can ping most Lorawan locations within a couple miles, and often 5+ miles. With a small cell CBRS unit you're talking about 100 M or 200 M in most cases. I believe we can get 1,000 good souls here to occasionally provide data on lorawan, but I'm not sure we can get 100,000 people to frequently provide data that would be robust enough to entice a major carrier. 3) FreedomFi is just one manufacturer, there's no requirement to have Lorawan on CBRS units and frankly a well placed CBRS unit is usually not a well placed Lorawan unit. So using Lorawan PoC as an incentive model is actually pretty miserable for CBRS. Personally I don't love them being combined. I'd suggest people just get 2 units and set each up where it will perform best. I don't hate the idea of having modular requirements in case a single location is good for both. 4) We NEED to decide as a network if we are going to be a multi bandwidth network or not. The Helium Inc messaging from day one has always been Helium != Lorawan, it was just the first protocol. If we do someday have the dream of this being a protocol agnostic network, we need to put the structures in place to support new bandwidths and drive incentives towards those that are going to have the best long term impact on the network. I get that this feels extreme right now, but it's only because this is the 1st new protocol.
3
09:32
Also @Steve (dewigo.com) I made that sheet view only for now. I need to make a copy that is not my working model for people to futz around with. Tab 1 is the current model, but there is still some polishing that needs to occur to handle edge cases.
09:33
@Anthonyra that is the case for the next 2 years.
Anthonyra 07/29/2021 9:33 AM
I didn't get clarification during the call if it was like today just the overage went to 5g. I didn't want it to be 30% for the next 2 years locked in
JMF 07/29/2021 9:33 AM
Then the division between PoC and DC goes away, which is going to happen in the protocol over the next like 5 years anyways.
09:34
It's also not locked in. It is based on % of DC burn of the bandwidth (also applies to future bandwidths) compared to the total DC burn of the network.
09:36
So CBRS is not currently walking into any significant PoC until DC usage starts to pick up. That being said, an innovation pool of like 5% to 10% has been considered for bandwidths sub 6 or 12 months old. Some bandwidths will have the same issue that Lorawan did and have no opportunity for DC usage until there is some network growth, so that gives them some room to grow. Same as the Lorawan setup.
Anthonyra 07/29/2021 9:40 AM
Shoot, make it 30% to new protocols and 30% to existing if we are doing it for 5g.. just split PoC at the second halving into two groups (old / new)...

JMF 07/29/2021 9:50 AM
@Deleted User that is the other big thing, if the goal is to be a bandwidth agnostic platform, there are going to be many cases where certain bandwidths are not available in certain areas.
2
Steve (dewigo.com)
the HW costs like $20. Its piggybacking on the existing HW. The FFi gateway costs similar as other vendors (less than some even, which is hilarious). It may be double the PoC but the two methods of PoC will be completely different with different antenna setup, different deploy strategy, different wiring and mounting needs..
Fizzy 07/29/2021 9:50 AM
Right, and my point on this is. Why would I buy any other gateway that is handicapped without 5G, when I can get one that is compatible for me to upgrade to 5G later. Answer I got on this was essentially "Tough luck for them, they better adapt. Business is business." So Freedomfi would now the only device literary capable of earning even more. When someone asks "Which gateway should I get, which one is better" the answer is "Well shit, go FreedomFi because you don't even need to use 5G, or can potentially get more if you wish to go 5G, or even more on secondary markets"

3
10:18
https://semtech.my.salesforce.com/sfc/p/#E0000000JelG/a/2R000000Q2YY/7hyal8gUewWREN8DSEk5R3Ee8OpqEuVOdsHpiAHb3jo
JMF
A couple massive points: 1) The carrier deals are going to be paramount to the CBRS wireless networks success and it's absolutely going to take time to build using data from the network. I am not in those discussions but I believe MOST CBRS units will not have access to roaming deals in their locations immediately or possibly for awhile, until one of the big 3 are signed up. So without any PoC, there will be literally 0 earnings on those units. 2) Yes we have mappers for Lorawan, but it's a relatively small number and the scale of what would be required for 5G is a magnitude or two bigger. It's worth remember that you can ping most Lorawan locations within a couple miles, and often 5+ miles. With a small cell CBRS unit you're talking about 100 M or 200 M in most cases. I believe we can get 1,000 good souls here to occasionally provide data on lorawan, but I'm not sure we can get 100,000 people to frequently provide data that would be robust enough to entice a major carrier. 3) FreedomFi is just one manufacturer, there's no requirement to have Lorawan on CBRS units and frankly a well placed CBRS unit is usually not a well placed Lorawan unit. So using Lorawan PoC as an incentive model is actually pretty miserable for CBRS. Personally I don't love them being combined. I'd suggest people just get 2 units and set each up where it will perform best. I don't hate the idea of having modular requirements in case a single location is good for both. 4) We NEED to decide as a network if we are going to be a multi bandwidth network or not. The Helium Inc messaging from day one has always been Helium != Lorawan, it was just the first protocol. If we do someday have the dream of this being a protocol agnostic network, we need to put the structures in place to support new bandwidths and drive incentives towards those that are going to have the best long term impact on the network. I get that this feels extreme right now, but it's only because this is the 1st new protocol.
Fizzy 07/29/2021 10:23 AM
1. I do not think this is in question. Yes we need to prove to carriers that we have units in place ready. But the method of PoC seems narrow and dependent on more development of an App by I would assume a single party with a vested interest in making, and which inherently requires having an eSIM device. I don't even have an eSIM device. I have an S10e and iPhone7. So unless I go out an upgrade, to a $500+ phone, I am locked out (Or I guess a old used Google Pixel). Many other people will be locked out like this. The list of eSIM compatible devices are limited, more so the BRANDS. So then there is that, recommending what BRAND someone would need to get, to get this coin, on what is supposed to be a decentralized wireless network (which using this term really does confuse me when we talking about 5g and how 'decentralized' this side of the project really is). Then on another hand, I am confused on how this information is passed on to a representative high enough any of the big 3 to make such a big deal. I can only assume it goes "Hey look at this app that confirms coverage on 5g.". If I was a multi billion dollar C*O for any company, why would there be trust in an app developed. Even if I had some code monkeys review the code/data points and make sure it is legit, it seems dubious. Touching back on lorawan mappers, Joey is making that pretty much free of charge. Obviously verifying trusted mapper data has been the biggest barrier of lorawan coverage mapping and getting a payout for that, aka prevent gaming. But I think allocating a % to an untested mapper method for 5G will be ill-advised, as no one has really had a chance to break and game it. Decided to split these up seeing how I am a talker. point 2 #soon. (edited)

Fizzy 07/29/2021 11:05 AM

BFGNeil - Trackpac.io 07/29/2021 12:32 PM

ChiefGolan 07/29/2021 12:49 PM
lets say the cost for a 5g miner is around 5000-8000$ cost for the setup They will need to make around 2-3 thousand dollars a month for a 3-4 month ROI. That means these miners need to make 200 HNT a month (current prices). The POC 5G is 30% of the 32.5% that is DC burn (spills to POC) So lets say 9-11% of all HNT distribution. That means a pool of 200,000 HNT a month (after halving), lets say there are 10,000k 5g nodes. 20 hnt a month for each 5g node (they still need 180 HNT for a 3-4 month ROI) How much lorawan is losing? 200,000 hnt, lets say there are 200,000k miners by the end of the year. Each lora hotspot loses 1 HNT a month (13$) to give 5G nodes a boost that they need. I think this loss is worth it! I was conservative with all my numbers you can play around with them in different ways. This boost only happens if there is usage in the first place. and is probably helpful to attract the big companies right? These are flat numbers so take with a grain of salt... Are my numbers correct (at least good haha) @Tushar @JMF These number were done at 2am if you have anything to fix in the numbers please do xD (edited)
The_Professional 07/29/2021 1:23 PM
That price is on the higher end of the spectrum. Most simple installs are going to be under 2k. Single radio and single gateway in a small coffee shop type install.
1
The_Professional
That price is on the higher end of the spectrum. Most simple installs are going to be under 2k. Single radio and single gateway in a small coffee shop type install.
ChiefGolan 07/29/2021 1:28 PM

13:28

13:29
