pirate_rollinson 07/30/2021 4:36 PM
You can't install CBRS base stations on a moving platform (like a boat). You're also not allowed to use it to connect anything airborne (drones).
Aloha 1 07/30/2021 4:38 PM
oh, Okay
16:39
so no RV (Mini Van) neither?
pirate_rollinson 07/30/2021 4:46 PM
No, not for base stations. You can trailer a base station but cannot operate it unless it is stationary.
Aloha 1 07/30/2021 4:50 PM
Okayã€‚Thank you (edited)
pirate_rollinson
You can't install CBRS base stations on a moving platform (like a boat). You're also not allowed to use it to connect anything airborne (drones).
The_Professional 07/30/2021 5:12 PM
Awesome. I'm glad that's the answer. I really didn't want to do it anyway. I appreciate the help.
The_Professional
Awesome. I'm glad that's the answer. I really didn't want to do it anyway. I appreciate the help.
pirate_rollinson 07/30/2021 5:32 PM
No worries. The dynamic spectrum allocation process for CBRS can be summarized as; Base station power up. Acquire GPS lock and lat/long Or CPI inputs lat/long CPI digitally signs off Base station says hello to configured SAS server or Proxy Base station sends configuration information and requests frequency allocation SAS verifies digital signature of CPI. SAS queries database for the specified location spectrum availability. SAS responds to base station with channels and power settings and says ok to tx. Base station up Base station heartbeats with SAS at regular intervals (up to 4 min I think) to confirm it is still active. If base station fails to heartbeat, base station is assumed offline and channels are deallocated, thatâ€™s not immediately after missing 1 heartbeat there are buffers built in. So, if the gps changes the base station stops tx and makes a new request with new coordinates. Therefore, no moving base stations.
4
pirate_rollinson
No worries. The dynamic spectrum allocation process for CBRS can be summarized as; Base station power up. Acquire GPS lock and lat/long Or CPI inputs lat/long CPI digitally signs off Base station says hello to configured SAS server or Proxy Base station sends configuration information and requests frequency allocation SAS verifies digital signature of CPI. SAS queries database for the specified location spectrum availability. SAS responds to base station with channels and power settings and says ok to tx. Base station up Base station heartbeats with SAS at regular intervals (up to 4 min I think) to confirm it is still active. If base station fails to heartbeat, base station is assumed offline and channels are deallocated, thatâ€™s not immediately after missing 1 heartbeat there are buffers built in. So, if the gps changes the base station stops tx and makes a new request with new coordinates. Therefore, no moving base stations.
The_Professional 07/30/2021 5:46 PM
I had a feeling it had to do with the gps. Thank you.

Fizzy 07/31/2021 5:03 PM
I guess ill put forth my next criticization of the witness app. Assuming anyone can go forth to these 5G spots and PoC right... Do we really want a "Pokemon GO" style phenomenon, where these 5G zones are crowded with people that want to "Mine" hnt? I am sure all of us have seen this, and how it can really hinder business via people loitering . And on the opposite side, if a 5G zone is within a restricted/private area, how will anyone but the 5G owners/business be able to participate and earn from this PoC. That definitively would not be fair, nor decentralized.

ferebee 08/02/2021 10:41 AM
Wow guys, I love the passion. âœŠ Some thoughts...
10:42
Is it reasonable to extrapolate Helium LoRa DC burn rate from @The_Professionalâ€™s installations, which I gather are for specific enterprise customers? If Helium LoRa achieves sufficient coverage, it could become the default network for many forms of consumer IoT, which so far has had to rely on Wi-Fi, occasionally LTE for high-value applications, or simply wasnâ€™t practical. It seems to me that widespread consumer usage could dwarf the bandwidth of enterprise applications.
10:42
We do need significant DC burn by the next halvening to support the profitability of mining, but with HIP-20, the event horizon for achieving full BME has been pushed out by several years. As discussed in the HIP, it opens Helium to established crypto capital markets.
10:42
Iâ€™m all for 5G, but donâ€™t count LoRa out yet.
TechScaler
What is the Wifi Offload coming out in January that is being referred to on the Discord call last week ?
ferebee 08/02/2021 11:04 AM
Wi-Fi offloading is a mechanism that allows a carrier to direct a userâ€™s device to use certain available Wi-Fi networks instead of LTE/5G. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_data_offloading The user doesnâ€™t need to connect to the Wi-Fi manually, so offloading can provide extra bandwidth even if the user might otherwise be unwilling to connect to unsafe and untrusted Wi-Fi networks. Since the CBRS mechanism that will enable Helium LTE/5G is available in the US but not worldwide, FreedomFi is proposing to offer Wi-Fi offload instead in other countries. If Helium 5G will go for $0.50/GB, it remains to be seen how much Wi-Fi offload will sell for. OTOH it will probably have a much lower cost of entry.
Mobile data offloading
Mobile data offloading is the use of complementary network technologies for delivering data originally targeted for cellular networks. Offloading reduces the amount of data being carried on the cellular bands, freeing bandwidth for other users. It is also used in situations where local cell reception may be poor, allowing the user to connect via...
ferebee
Wi-Fi offloading is a mechanism that allows a carrier to direct a userâ€™s device to use certain available Wi-Fi networks instead of LTE/5G. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_data_offloading The user doesnâ€™t need to connect to the Wi-Fi manually, so offloading can provide extra bandwidth even if the user might otherwise be unwilling to connect to unsafe and untrusted Wi-Fi networks. Since the CBRS mechanism that will enable Helium LTE/5G is available in the US but not worldwide, FreedomFi is proposing to offer Wi-Fi offload instead in other countries. If Helium 5G will go for $0.50/GB, it remains to be seen how much Wi-Fi offload will sell for. OTOH it will probably have a much lower cost of entry.
TechScaler 08/02/2021 11:32 AM
Thank you @ferebee . So I guess the mention of WiFi6 is also in the same context right.
1
ferebee
Is it reasonable to extrapolate Helium LoRa DC burn rate from @The_Professionalâ€™s installations, which I gather are for specific enterprise customers? If Helium LoRa achieves sufficient coverage, it could become the default network for many forms of consumer IoT, which so far has had to rely on Wi-Fi, occasionally LTE for high-value applications, or simply wasnâ€™t practical. It seems to me that widespread consumer usage could dwarf the bandwidth of enterprise applications.
The_Professional 08/02/2021 4:28 PM
I'm all for growing the network. I'm all for every household having a Lora sensor. I want to see Lora help save people's lives. But let's not forget we're living in an unprecedented times. Everybody lost the year because of COVID-19. I know we had five contracts that we were working on in 2020 that all got put on hold. Only one of those contracts came back 2021. Residential sensors are far and few between and unless some companies come out with easy ways to implement them in consumer ways it's not going to happen. There's new lockdowns for a lot of places with mean people are not working again. There's no free-flowing money. Evictions in the USA are going to start happening in the next few months if not next year so that means there's going to be less consumer spending. Then there's a shortage of materials and huge inflation to add to it. I'm just saying hey let's look at the big picture. A normalcy in people's lives might not happen until sometime in 2023 which is already a second halving. The only way I see this being sustainable is if all Enterprise solutions had the ability to do an OTA and have helium. Packet forwarders need to get online which isn't going to happen until later this year. Adding more hot spots doesn't solve the solution. It helps with coverage but it doesn't mean that it will save helium. T-Mobile can have a million cell towers and radios but if no one's using it they're still going to go bankrupt. (edited)
16:32
I'm also not saying 5G is the answer. And I'm aware it doesn't help the people in the rest of the world. But I do believe that we need to work on steps to get data flowing. If helium wants to be an iot service provider 5G, 4g, Wi-Fi and Bluetooth should be stuff that we look at
ferebee 08/03/2021 2:44 AM
Yes to everything except Bluetooth, a Helium hotspot every 5 meters is not the way to save the world!
Aloha 1 08/03/2021 9:12 AM
I want a LoraWAN security Camera in consumer base.
The_Professional 08/03/2021 11:54 AM
They have Lora security cameras. But the video doesn't get transmitted via Lora. It's typically gsm(LTE/5G), wired or wifi.. the only thing sending through Lora is the motion detection..
11:56
Lora has a lot of really good use cases but most are not large data. It's very small packets then meant to go into a deep sleep to wake up 15 mins- hour later to update the state.
Aloha 1 08/03/2021 11:59 AM
5G are all over my city.
Aloha 1
Yes. We need 5G sensors more
TechScaler 08/03/2021 2:10 PM
5G IoT Sensors are very few.. still ways to go.. but there are enough LTE/4G based sensors that will work with 5G networks (provided CBRS band is supported) . Big issue with CBRS is range is limited for each small cell 300-500m so the sensor should be in range (unlike LoRA which can work for miles) (edited)

TechScaler 08/03/2021 4:52 PM
I spent significant time trying to understand the new CBRS POC tokenomics model . I am stuck on the formula on Cell C49 "Final NLP NC-PoC rewards". Based on what I understood this will be 30% of unused DC rewards will be used for NLP POC. Shouldn't this be as simple as 30% of [Net DC Reward Max (F12) - Net DC Burn (C28)] = 30%(828750-350000). I see some other formula there that i don't understand. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1C8G06_MgFYPrttVKp4KrgKSPalTZ1L8ausymPxnQh6A/edit#gid=1169066097
HNT CBRS Mining Scenarios_v2

119vik 08/04/2021 1:00 AM
@hashc0de what's size of blockchain on miners SSD these days ?
119vik
@hashc0de what's size of blockchain on miners SSD these days ?
hashc0de 08/04/2021 7:27 AM
Almost not important since they are all chain followers. In fact our miner start script in our OG miner firmware automatically cleans directories when disk utilization goes over 90%.
07:28
The smallest SD cards in miners are 32GB though
JMF 08/04/2021 9:03 AM
@TechScaler not exactly. It's actually % of the entire PoC bucket up until you max out the DC bucket. Since making that initial model, I've come to think of some ways to simplify it, but I'm slammed with other work at the moment and haven't gotten to it.
09:06
Honestly, that model was made between the hours of midnight and 3am and went through like 5 variations to account for different edge cases, so the complexity of the equations grew exponentially. Now that the math generally works out agains more simplified back of the napkin math, I need to rebuild it from scratch knowing everything I know now.
09:08
I'd suggest you take the info to make directionally correct decisions rather than trying to reverse engineer and overcomplex thought process, at least until the new model is done.
09:09
The short of it is that NLPs get screwed in the current system and always will, they get a little less screwed while Lorawan still benefits a good deal in the new model until the 2nd halving and then there total rewards are on par with their DC burn after the 2nd halving.
JMF
@TechScaler not exactly. It's actually % of the entire PoC bucket up until you max out the DC bucket. Since making that initial model, I've come to think of some ways to simplify it, but I'm slammed with other work at the moment and haven't gotten to it.

Publicly-accessible Metabase instances
I run a Metabase instance for an open-source blockchain project called Helium: https://helium.com â€“ our Metabase is here: https://etl.dewi.org Our goal is to provide this as a public service for the community, since it is difficult to run a full node and the associated postgres database. Requires maintenance, 400GB+ in storage, lots of RAM, etc...

14:56

The_Professional 08/06/2021 4:12 PM
At the moment I think they are just trying to get this going. They're having trouble just even getting accepted on the helium Network because there's so many people against the 5G POC. I'm sure these questions will be answered but I think we're still years away from these types of deployments. Right now their goal is low power indoor installs. Baicell and sercomm radios. FF will be the CPI that signs off on installs. Using residential ISP backhaul.. I know @pirate_rollinson (sorry to disturb you) could answer some of these questions a lot better than I can but right now they're learning to crawl.

I come from Enterprise Lora installs. I totally understand your thought process and wanting to jump ahead. At the beginning they're trying to make this more consumer friendly. The_Professional 08/06/2021 8:00 PM

hs.EQ
concept is pretty radical but the path to execution is what i am trying to figure out for the deployment model
pirate_rollinson 08/07/2021 12:16 AM
Path to execution, due to the high capex involved to deploy Helium 5G, is obviously critical. If I was a challenger MVNO looking to make a bit of headline for not much cost, Helium 5G is just crazy enough, while being relatively low risk. If it turns out to be a dud, they just won't use it and will carry on doing business as usual. If it takes off, they're first, and they get dirt cheap access to a network growing faster than any traditional network operator could ever hope to achieve. It's bold, so they need a bold mvno to sign on. Is consumer the only market? I don't think so, but it's a fact that the first big user will influence the rollout. When we find out who that is in September we can decide whether to exercise our reservations.

TechScaler 08/09/2021 4:13 PM

TechScaler 08/09/2021 4:27 PM
As I understand it, If a building owner has cameras uploading TB of data to the cloud over helium cbrs, they would technically need to get SIM or eSIM from MNO/MVNO who is partnered with FreedomFi. While as a Helium host, we charge only $0.50/GB, the MNO/MVNO may charge much more and technically pose data limits to their users. It will be great idea , if we could also have a model where a Helium CBRS host can allow upload data directly to the cloud (without involvement of MNO and MVNO) for the right business opportunity. (edited)
TechScaler
Tushar, can you explain how it would be free ?.
para2 08/09/2021 4:27 PM
you pay to push the data but your hotspot mines the DC back
TechScaler 08/09/2021 4:57 PM

Tushar 08/09/2021 5:43 PM
Oh thatâ€™s an interesting question
17:44
Maybe we can ask @zer0tweets to chime in on whether the Helium 5G implementation allows for a user to bypass the MNO/MVNO for direct use
hashc0de 08/09/2021 6:12 PM
The network is ambivalent to the device or the buyer of the "packets". If the Hotspot can present an offer to a purchaser (Router/similar) and the Purchaser is willing to burn DCs and accept that offer, the Hotspot can be rewarded. What the Hotspot does with that LTE session is sort of on them. Ideally the way you'd do this is that the Device owner sends DCs into the Purchaser that provides them the "SLA" here so that when they encounter a Hotspot, they know they'll get service. (edited)
1
Tushar
Maybe we can ask @zer0tweets to chime in on whether the Helium 5G implementation allows for a user to bypass the MNO/MVNO for direct use
zer0tweets 08/09/2021 7:54 PM
Yes, it's totally possible. The issue is if if it's cost effective. Would you want to stream surveillance video at 50 cents a gig?
19:55
The setup can technically make it possible to zero rate traffic coming through particular cells too and bypass Helium altogether, but that won't really bring traffic to the network and won't mine anything
1
Tushar 08/09/2021 8:21 PM
If itâ€™s your own hotspot, maybe? But yeah, probably not worth it
zer0tweets
The setup can technically make it possible to zero rate traffic coming through particular cells too and bypass Helium altogether, but that won't really bring traffic to the network and won't mine anything
TechScaler 08/10/2021 7:00 AM
Based on several years in this space, I can share many cellular IoT based customers, who will be delighted to pay $0.50/GB for a CBRS based backhaul. MNOs today charge almost $10-$12/GB for these use cases. What we need is a eSIM AND physical SIM (since many iot devices do not support eSIM) that a host operating CBRS in say a mall can offer its tenants. Very much like a prepaid sim card, the host would offer a "host branded SIM card" . In the background, host buys data credits from Helium and offer the tenant say 100GB package at say $100-$200 to the tenants ( a handsome 2x-4x profit). This 100GB of data would not go through an MNO/MVNO but gets directly sent to the internet by the FreedomFi gateway. What is needed here is the ability for FreedomFi gateway to have routing intelligence to deal with the "host branded SIM card" in addition to allowing MNO/MVNO SIMs on the hosts network. (edited)
1
TechScaler 08/10/2021 7:23 AM
Another more scalable and probably more secure would be helium branded sim cards that work with Freedom Fi use DC as the currency.
TechScaler
As I understand it, If a building owner has cameras uploading TB of data to the cloud over helium cbrs, they would technically need to get SIM or eSIM from MNO/MVNO who is partnered with FreedomFi. While as a Helium host, we charge only $0.50/GB, the MNO/MVNO may charge much more and technically pose data limits to their users. It will be great idea , if we could also have a model where a Helium CBRS host can allow upload data directly to the cloud (without involvement of MNO and MVNO) for the right business opportunity. (edited)

You'd need to have a way to issue eSIMs for that network but still doable.

Deirgnerp 08/11/2021 10:33 AM
What am I missing here. Can helium 5g happen outside of the US ? Or no! ? !
10:35
Iâ€™ve soo many thoughts on this. But from what I can understand, the licensing for EU is prohibitively expensiveâ€¦
Deirgnerp
What am I missing here. Can helium 5g happen outside of the US ? Or no! ? !
pirate_rollinson 08/11/2021 11:19 AM
Yes, but that's because US is the first country to use a dynamic licensing system for the CBRS range of spectrum. B48 LTE-TDD N48 5G. In the UK, Band 42 is available for licensing at low cost, 800 GBP I think, but there's an application process. As more countries roll out dynamic spectrum access you can expect Helium 5G to grow. The global patchwork of frequency availability/management is the largest barrier. Legacy, nation-state friction is mightily powerful, especially when it comes to licensed frequencies. Carriers don't like the idea, at all, and will defend their perceived territory at all costs with lobbying etc. So lobby your local governments to open up spectrum. maybe some of the A16Z funding will help that. (edited)
1
Aloha 1
I am not sure but when I see Freedomfi first announcement in April that they said it covers 3G,4G,LTE and 5G. They only mention 5G now. sorry if it's my misunderstanding. (edited)
TechScaler 08/11/2021 1:53 PM
Typically as long as the hardware is 5G capable, LTE to 5G is a software update
1
13:54
For the initial deployment of FreedomFi, would it be limited to certain cities/regions in US ?
pirate_rollinson
Yes, but that's because US is the first country to use a dynamic licensing system for the CBRS range of spectrum. B48 LTE-TDD N48 5G. In the UK, Band 42 is available for licensing at low cost, 800 GBP I think, but there's an application process. As more countries roll out dynamic spectrum access you can expect Helium 5G to grow. The global patchwork of frequency availability/management is the largest barrier. Legacy, nation-state friction is mightily powerful, especially when it comes to licensed frequencies. Carriers don't like the idea, at all, and will defend their perceived territory at all costs with lobbying etc. So lobby your local governments to open up spectrum. maybe some of the A16Z funding will help that. (edited)

The_Professional 08/11/2021 3:50 PM
Without B&M there isn't going to be a network..Lora is still years behind before there is any real data moving through the network. We can't talk price of the coin but that's the incentive. You can have less coming in but if the price is higher per coin it pays off. With this investment maybe a big telecommunication company does ink a deal but without a network it's going to be a hard sell. I don't know if those investors want to come in and drop 100 and something million dollars to build out a network. If that's the case then that's a lot of deployments. That's digging into your money. That's not the small people anymore. It makes the budget I have looks small in comparison when they're investing 20 times more than I have planned. (edited)
Deirgnerp 08/11/2021 4:20 PM
Lora was years behind due to chicken/egg situation. adding the crypto incentive neatly circumvented the who and how of building the network. â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”- In the beginning. Not that long ago! 100% of the spots were in the US. Today, with over 80k spots online, the 4.2% of the people who live in the US, operate just 50% of the spots. The majority percentage of operators residing in the US currently, will be eclipsed in due course, as it gets built out worldwide. The (US) peopleâ€™s network is becoming the global peopleâ€™s network. Regarding how to incentivise 5gâ€¦. Relying on a, hurriedly on boarded, US centric, unproven protocol model, to drive the speculative value of the hnt token for the +32,000 Lora hotspot operators globally. Seemsâ€¦ impetuous/hasty/myopic/US-centric/risky? Take your pick. The ambition thatâ€™s driving this move is laudable. But the consequences of cannibalising the incentive structure, thatâ€™s driving this incredible growth, at this early stage raises many questions and will likely hinder the momentum achieved. Why no 5G token?

But the consequences of cannibalising the incentive structure, thatâ€™s driving this incredible growth, at this early stage raises many questions and will likely hinder the momentum achieved. Why no 5G token?
The_Professional 08/11/2021 5:08 PM
Who is going to be the Dev? It's taken 5 year for helium to get here.
The_Professional 08/11/2021 5:22 PM
I know very large lora companies that are not interested in helium. It's far from solving any issue. All the companies need to do is install their own lora gateway and not have to worry about helium. Solves their issue. Also, what happens when their is a power outage? The network dies. Real companies think about this. I have sensors in FL at the moment awaiting this storm. If the power goes out then I don't get any sensor data. Data that can save people lives. Doesn't solve that issue. Want to say helium is a nationwide service? It's not. Let say you install a lora gps module on your $700k lambo. Someone steals it from you. All they have to do is drive to an area without helium gateways and poof. That's why most gps tracking uses gsm. That's a liability for my company. I also know how much data is sent by lora. It's max size is 256 bytes with most sensors sending less than that. Let's say I am trying to move lora and some other form of data like video data. Why not just move it through 5g/4g? I can do both. "Helium is now evolving and has embarked on the path to deploy a 5G cellular network of gateways and hotspots. Weâ€™re excited about Heliumâ€™s potential to provide comprehensive 5G connectivity across the world in a way thatâ€™s faster and more capital-efficient than traditional telecom infrastructure." I know lora and I know what it can do. If helium sticks to just lora I will sell all my stuff and not bother. That is why 5G was brought up by the investor. It is what it is. It's going to piss people off but without it helium is losing it's legs to stand on. Here's another thing. I can't bid on a job with Helium. I can't tell my customer there is a 20 week lead time for your gatways. I can call cisco and have a pallet sent to me within a couple weeks. (edited)

The_Professional 08/12/2021 10:05 AM
It's 500-1000 units in September shipped. New pre-orders start then. All first batch pre-orders will be shipped out by January. Indoor radios ship out in October and outdoor radios comes out in November. Data will start transferring in November.

Zac 08/12/2021 10:30 AM
Really appreciate all the knowledge and experience you share. I'm wondering though, except for the lead time for gateways, wouldn't helium be a better option for established network builders as they benefit from poc rewards and, eventually, data transmission by other users of the network? Though I can see how the crypto side might scare people off.
Zac 08/12/2021 10:42 AM
5g POC idea: how about a per 5g hotspot daily cap on rewards? (Maybe this has already been considered.) I imagine something like 10 HNT per day per 5g hotspot, with the remainder of the daily rewards staying on the Lora side. At some point there are enough 5g hotspots that all of the allotment is used by 5g hotspots and their per unit share begins to diminish. Whatever the initial daily limit, it could be designed around incentivizing some number of 5g hotspots by end of 2022.

The_Professional 08/12/2021 11:29 AM
Tldr hardware is not up to snuff to compete with the Enterprise grade stuff. There's a hip being released about advanced diagnostics but it's still in conversation. there's no trust in it because companies know there's an incentive with the cryptocurrency but what happens when that incentive goes away. There's the lead times for companies to get hardware with dismal support from these companies. Look at nebra and look at sybcrobit. People are trying to sue them. Now if we also look outside of helium and look at current economics. Most countries are circling the rim of another lockdown. The infrastructure bill can help build some more Lora. But at the same time at taxes cryptocurrencies which means some people will think it's not worth it. We're also circling the rim of a recession. Adoption rates and consumer sensors is going to go down. And if the recession is large enough more commercial projects will be put on hold like they did in 2020. We have contracts that was supposed to be started in 2020 but now have a start date of 2022. Helium does have a lot going for it but it has things against it that it can't control.. there's more to this but it's already becoming long-winded. I'm not against the daily limit. You can also have which is greater the daily limit or data moved.. so if you moved 1tb from the radio you won't get the 10 hnt. Whichever is greater. (edited)

JMF 08/13/2021 8:20 PM
Something that seems to getting lost here is that CBRS PoC rewards are limited as a % of total DC burn going through that protocol compared to the total network and even then itâ€™s limited to the DC reward bucket for 2 years. That bucket was never supposed to go to Lorawan PoC but it was a bandaid fix for the shit show that led to HIP10 (all those that were there know what I mean). I take blame for the lack of understanding on that point because the final HIP is still being finalized (mostly handling security concerns). (edited)
20:23
Sorry if that was still confusing but if we have say 1 M PoC rewards in a month across the entire network and CBRS is only burning 5% of the total DCs in the network it is only allocated 5% of that PoC or 50k HNT a month. The DC burn cannibalizes the CBRS PoC bucket because the two combined can only equal ~35% of total HNT minted per month for the next 2 years, which was a mechanism to protect Lorawan from other protocols eating into their PoC rewards for a couple years.
10

Franco Canova 08/27/2021 9:46 AM
Hi everyone! I've been reading a bit about this project and have a question. The network we are out to build has the final objective of serving companies/apps/people that want to transmit data packets though our network. At the end of the day a key factor for the users is the price we charge them for transmitting data. Having said that, I've been making some calculations of costs in my country (specifically for mobile roaming, knowing the next big thing in Helium is 5G) and I found that using Helium is not competitive against local telecoms. Is there any HIP in progress to tackle this problem? Prices per "datapacket" should vary depending on country/location in my opinion, or else we cant compete.
Franco Canova
Hi everyone! I've been reading a bit about this project and have a question. The network we are out to build has the final objective of serving companies/apps/people that want to transmit data packets though our network. At the end of the day a key factor for the users is the price we charge them for transmitting data. Having said that, I've been making some calculations of costs in my country (specifically for mobile roaming, knowing the next big thing in Helium is 5G) and I found that using Helium is not competitive against local telecoms. Is there any HIP in progress to tackle this problem? Prices per "datapacket" should vary depending on country/location in my opinion, or else we cant compete.
Tushar 08/27/2021 10:35 AM
that is exactly what is addressed in this HIP. check out the pinned link
Tushar
that is exactly what is addressed in this HIP. check out the pinned link
Franco Canova 08/27/2021 10:39 AM

linagee 08/31/2021 2:54 AM
Is LTE-U (LTE in the 5GHz unlicensed spectrum, band 46) even easier to get up and running than CBRS LTE (band 48)? Is there a license approval required even? Is band 46 more available on phones than band 48? Interesting. In Google searches, Band 46 / Band 48 seem to have VZW's name on them for whatever reason. (They would probably work with any carrier as long as the phone can talk on that band.) Are our partner MVNOs VZW based? (edited)
linagee
Is LTE-U (LTE in the 5GHz unlicensed spectrum, band 46) even easier to get up and running than CBRS LTE (band 48)? Is there a license approval required even? Is band 46 more available on phones than band 48? Interesting. In Google searches, Band 46 / Band 48 seem to have VZW's name on them for whatever reason. (They would probably work with any carrier as long as the phone can talk on that band.) Are our partner MVNOs VZW based? (edited)
Bobert McBob 08/31/2021 3:34 AM
The only major requirement for running on band 46 is that you keep under the power limits.
03:34
I've done it using a beefy computer and an SDR because I was curious.
1

https://advanced-television.com/2021/03/17/uk-5g-spectrum-auction-raises-1-35bn/ https://advanced-television.com/2021/04/27/uk-5g-spectrum-auction-final-results/ https://enterpriseiotinsights.com/20191004/channels/news/vodafone-first-to-open-lte-band-for-private-usage There's been talks in the UK since 2018 about opening up a spectrum. They recently had the spectrum auction in March but if you read through the articles I sent you now it's up to the telecommunication companies to negotiate within themselves. There's no exact date when it's going to be a thing you can use. Here is the proposed 5G poc https://docs.google.com/document/d/10hlVfbNLHv1Wm8hU7SyqBBZis78icW9a21SY9RxavzA/edit#heading=h.8ly3w9klpso You can also see #hip-37-omni-protocol-poc

The typical Helium gateway (based on either LoRa or 5G) uses infinitesimal amounts of data as compared to Netflix, Pluto, Fubo, etc. No idea as to the actual numbers but probably not much to worry about unless/until ISPs start going after those much more data hungry services.

The typical Helium gateway (based on either LoRa or 5G) uses infinitesimal amounts of data as compared to Netflix, Pluto, Fubo, etc. No idea as to the actual numbers but probably not much to worry about unless/until ISPs start going after those much more data hungry services.

matmanmining

The_Professional 09/23/2021 11:40 AM
So cbrs radios cap out around 125mbps passthrough. Some radios are higher but the highest you'll see is ~220. If you have one radio connected you should be too worried about getting it terminated. Having 4-5 radios and tapping out 1gbps sustained then your ISP might say something.
The_Professional
So cbrs radios cap out around 125mbps passthrough. Some radios are higher but the highest you'll see is ~220. If you have one radio connected you should be too worried about getting it terminated. Having 4-5 radios and tapping out 1gbps sustained then your ISP might say something.
matmanmining 09/23/2021 12:01 PM
OK, that is good to know. So I am running Gig fiber, the most of the bandwidth used would be 12.5 to 22%? I know this is all based on speculation, but I am wondering how my ISP will react to this usage. Since it will be a gradual increase, maybe they will not have any reason to notice??
matmanmining

The_Professional 09/23/2021 12:06 PM
125 mbps probably nothing. We're not going to do any home installs as to us it's not worth our efforts. Typically business internet shouldn't have these issues.

ferebee 09/24/2021 3:31 AM
PoC continues for existing LoRa installations with slight future reductions as PoC rewards are introduced for the (comparatively few) new CBRS installations. OTOH to the extent that Helium/CBRS is successful, DC burn for Data Transfer will ramp up much more quickly than it ever could for LoRa, bringing commercial value to the same Helium blockchain that pays out to LoRa. Both will profit.

Zwibbledibble42 09/29/2021 1:16 PM
So I'm trying to understand the incentives for early adoption of the freedomfi 5g hotspots. Apologies for sleeping on this, but my understanding is as follows: Since the only earning from 5g (in the near term) is due to dc usage, if you buy a freedomfi hotspot/small cell you will only earn if you're in a place where a bunch of people who use gigsky esims are using data. In my brief time on google I haven't been able to find a firm number for how many individuals that would be, but I'm assuming relatively few compared to the people who are just on one of the big carriers. I understand that we need to work with smaller MVNOs to figure out reliability to enable deals with larger MNOs, but until that happens, those who deploy small cells will likely be fairly limited in the number of dcs they can push, and thus the rewards they can be expected to receive. At $0.5/gb, and capping rewards at the value of data transferred through a node, until PoC goes live in the future, the incentives thus seem fairly small compared to the total cost of the entire setup. (This is with me imagining you get one or two gigsky people per day, who scroll through their IG stories while they wait for their coffee, burning a few MB of data)
13:16
I did a little more reading though, and need some clarification on something I found in one of the gigsky launch articles: "The first 5 gigabytes of US nationwide cellular data and unlimited data on self-hosted Helium 5G infrastructure will be available to all members of the Helium community who purchase and deploy the Helium 5G bundle from CalChip Connect and download the GigSky app. The GigSky app will seamlessly roam between its nationwide US network and the Helium-based CBRS offload network, prioritizing the latter where coverage is available, thus optimizing cost to the consumer. As the Helium cellular network expands its coverage over time, it is expected that the cost of cellular data on the network will eventually retail for 50 cents per gigabyte." https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2021/09/23/2302261/0/en/GigSky-First-to-Launch-Cellular-Data-on-the-Helium-Blockchain.html
GigSky First to Launch Cellular Data on the Helium Blockchain
GigSky partners with FreedomFi and CalChip to launch US Nationwide mobile data plan using worldâ€™s first blockchain-powered neutral host network...
13:16
Does the bolded imply that we could set up a 5g small cell in our home, download the gigsky app and just plug away, upping data transfer across our small cell but with no cost? This seems wrong to me, which is why Iâ€™m bringing it here. Iâ€™m also not sure if Iâ€™m accurately understanding the incentives for early adoption well, maybe im underestimating the number of gigsky customers/the total rewards per DC? Is my contrived oversimplification of 5g usage roughly accurate or am I missing something? Just trying to understand everything before I pull the trigger on my order. Thanks in advance!

Dephault 09/29/2021 1:28 PM
Great post ^ I am having the same questions @Zwibbledibble42
1
Zwibbledibble42
So I'm trying to understand the incentives for early adoption of the freedomfi 5g hotspots. Apologies for sleeping on this, but my understanding is as follows: Since the only earning from 5g (in the near term) is due to dc usage, if you buy a freedomfi hotspot/small cell you will only earn if you're in a place where a bunch of people who use gigsky esims are using data. In my brief time on google I haven't been able to find a firm number for how many individuals that would be, but I'm assuming relatively few compared to the people who are just on one of the big carriers. I understand that we need to work with smaller MVNOs to figure out reliability to enable deals with larger MNOs, but until that happens, those who deploy small cells will likely be fairly limited in the number of dcs they can push, and thus the rewards they can be expected to receive. At $0.5/gb, and capping rewards at the value of data transferred through a node, until PoC goes live in the future, the incentives thus seem fairly small compared to the total cost of the entire setup. (This is with me imagining you get one or two gigsky people per day, who scroll through their IG stories while they wait for their coffee, burning a few MB of data)
Steve (dewigo.com) 09/29/2021 1:41 PM
I think you understand the situation pretty well. Whats the early investor benefit? It's the only program in the world of its kind. Partners look limited right now -- if you buy the full kit its basically a bet that more partners come online in the future thus increasing utility and DC usage. Personally I find the lack of PoC rewards until 2H 2023 disheartening. OTOH, DC is stably pegged at $.50/gb regardless of market conditions so in a deeply bear market DC earnings might outshine any PoC potential. Either way, moving DCs further increases the benefits of PoC.
3

Zwibbledibble42
I did a little more reading though, and need some clarification on something I found in one of the gigsky launch articles: "The first 5 gigabytes of US nationwide cellular data and unlimited data on self-hosted Helium 5G infrastructure will be available to all members of the Helium community who purchase and deploy the Helium 5G bundle from CalChip Connect and download the GigSky app. The GigSky app will seamlessly roam between its nationwide US network and the Helium-based CBRS offload network, prioritizing the latter where coverage is available, thus optimizing cost to the consumer. As the Helium cellular network expands its coverage over time, it is expected that the cost of cellular data on the network will eventually retail for 50 cents per gigabyte." https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2021/09/23/2302261/0/en/GigSky-First-to-Launch-Cellular-Data-on-the-Helium-Blockchain.html
Zwibbledibble42 09/30/2021 12:16 PM
Does anyone have insight into this portion of my question, regarding unlimited data on self-hosted helium infrastructure?
Zwibbledibble42
Does anyone have insight into this portion of my question, regarding unlimited data on self-hosted helium infrastructure?
TechScaler 09/30/2021 12:22 PM
This is a good question. Below is my understanding. People correct me if i am wrong. Even though you bought the cbrs radio, pay for backhaul setup the infrastructure (in your home for example), you will need to burn data credits to use the cbrs radio. If data passes through the FFi box, someone needs to pay for the DCs. Gigsky simply buys DCs from Helium and allows their customers (who have Gigsky e-sim installed) to use it.
TechScaler
This is a good question. Below is my understanding. People correct me if i am wrong. Even though you bought the cbrs radio, pay for backhaul setup the infrastructure (in your home for example), you will need to burn data credits to use the cbrs radio. If data passes through the FFi box, someone needs to pay for the DCs. Gigsky simply buys DCs from Helium and allows their customers (who have Gigsky e-sim installed) to use it.
Zwibbledibble42 09/30/2021 12:28 PM
Thanks @TechScaler . my question is regarding the statement in the posted article about people who set up a ffi small cell through helium getting access to "unlimited data on self hosted helium 5g infrastructure". Just based on the above bolded statement it would appear that I could set up a small cell, download the app and stream netflix through my phone 24/7 to push data that I don't pay for through the network. I don't have any more real info on this, so I'm probably misunderstanding something here

Bobert McBob 09/30/2021 11:57 PM

Zwibbledibble42
Thanks @TechScaler . my question is regarding the statement in the posted article about people who set up a ffi small cell through helium getting access to "unlimited data on self hosted helium 5g infrastructure". I don't have any more real info on this, so I'm probably misunderstanding something here
Anthonyra 10/04/2021 5:42 AM
I'm assuming, and this is a big one that it's because of the 1:1 DC to HNT from HIP10. However, if they don't charge you at all while passing data through your hotspot they would essentially be paying you "which seems well broken" but instead if they still charged you the DC to move the data you'd get HNT in your wallet at 1:1 since you're passing it through a hotspot you own. Meaning you'd spend 1 DC to and in return get 1 DC worth of HNT as a reward "free unlimited data" but you're still paying for the internet so it's not exactly "free"

meow 10/04/2021 8:42 AM
This could be speculatory, but based on the statement to me it stating Peer to Peer traffic , i.e. over the FreedomFI CBRS network would be free not necessarily egress traffic across any celluar network. In essence this is the Private Network that will be created across with the small cells, it would operate in the same sense as Private LTE or Current CBRS data as it stays "on-net" vs. traversing an EPC or Core with a peered upstream cellular provider (edited)

Chris 11/04/2021 11:34 AM
Seems that there's a desire to bring more manufacturers onboard eventually. I don't think it's ever going to make sense to try and upgrade today's LoRa hotspots to be 5G capable (I've seen that idea floated by some in-the-know people here, but IMO, it'll never make sense)
Chris
Seems that there's a desire to bring more manufacturers onboard eventually. I don't think it's ever going to make sense to try and upgrade today's LoRa hotspots to be 5G capable (I've seen that idea floated by some in-the-know people here, but IMO, it'll never make sense)
Tim | LongAP 11/04/2021 11:39 AM
Our hotspots are very comparable to FreedomFis (also x86/x64, multiple gigabit interfaces and so on) so it would be a logical step for us for our current platform. (edited)

Tim | LongAP
I know that, we are building the hotspots ourselves . I was wondering how we can change that. I canâ€™t imagine that the idea is that FreedomFi stays the only 5G Miner manufacturer.
pirate_rollinson 11/05/2021 7:53 AM
You'd have to build a mobile core, either EPC or 5G SA/NSA. Then you need to source FCC certified CBRS radios. Start with examining the magma-core project. It would be a non-trivial exercise, technical and architectural barriers are high.
pirate_rollinson
You'd have to build a mobile core, either EPC or 5G SA/NSA. Then you need to source FCC certified CBRS radios. Start with examining the magma-core project. It would be a non-trivial exercise, technical and architectural barriers are high.
pirate_rollinson 11/05/2021 7:56 AM
hmu if you want a demo of the Celona platform, that will give you an idea of what's involved.

Helium5G - FreedomFi
Earn HNT cryptocurrency by providing 5G cellular coverage. FreedomFi Gateway is the first omni-protocol miner for the Helium network. It will mine HNT for providing LoRa coverage, but is also expandable with certified CBRS small cells (and later Wi-Fi access points) to earn HNT cryptocurrency by offloading cellular data for carriers like DISH Wi...

pirate_rollinson 12/13/2021 4:28 PM
It will not. The Helium5G platform from Freedom Fi uses CBRS which is USA only
Pirro 12/13/2021 4:28 PM

pirate_rollinson 12/13/2021 4:31 PM
It will depend on local regulation for the 5G side. I don't know if the Brazilian authorities have released spectrum for Private Cellular. Support for WiFi handoff/hotspots will be available worldwide before Helium5G. That's why Hip 39 is omni protocol,

The_Professional 12/14/2021 12:25 PM

Pirro
Wich band should i buy for brazil?
Deleted User 12/15/2021 2:06 PM
Technically there is not a single Helium OEM that has received ANATEL (https://www.gov.br/anatel/pt-br) certification to date. So any AU915Mhz product you buy today is not licensed for Brazil. Two Brazilian companies have applied to build HW for the Brazil market (and possibly elsewhere) but they have not yet completed the DEWI MOC Audit process: https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hotspot-manufacturers/blob/main/illios-phygitall.md and https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hotspot-manufacturers/blob/main/applications/brdot.md
Anatel
hotspot-manufacturers/illios-phygitall.md at main · dewi-alliance/h...
Hub for Helium hotspot manfuacturer applications and the Manufacturer Oversight Committee (MOC) - hotspot-manufacturers/illios-phygitall.md at main · dewi-alliance/hotspot-manufacturers
hotspot-manufacturers/brdot.md at main · dewi-alliance/hotspot-manu...
Hub for Helium hotspot manfuacturer applications and the Manufacturer Oversight Committee (MOC) - hotspot-manufacturers/brdot.md at main · dewi-alliance/hotspot-manufacturers
Deleted User
Technically there is not a single Helium OEM that has received ANATEL (https://www.gov.br/anatel/pt-br) certification to date. So any AU915Mhz product you buy today is not licensed for Brazil. Two Brazilian companies have applied to build HW for the Brazil market (and possibly elsewhere) but they have not yet completed the DEWI MOC Audit process: https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hotspot-manufacturers/blob/main/illios-phygitall.md and https://github.com/dewi-alliance/hotspot-manufacturers/blob/main/applications/brdot.md

Bobcat_Marketing 03/15/2022 4:20 PM
Hi folks, Bobcat has launched the Bobber 500 today for Helium 5G. This is an industrial-grade CBRS gateway we co-engineered with FreedomFi. We are currently recruiting Pilot Users to take part in a field trial, where participants will pay for the equipment and receive a Bobber 500, a small cell (Freedomfi One) and an esim download link to help validate the network. If you're interested, fill out this questionnaire and we'll be in touch https://forms.gle/LK9YkHQttHT7fM8P9 (edited)
User Information
Thank you for interest in the Bobber 500 Pilot Program! We'll like to ask you a few questions about you, your interest in 5G, and your familiarity with the Helium network. We've tried to make this as quick and painless as possible, so it should only take a few minutes of your time. Note: You can fill out this form ONLY ONCE.
4
Bobcat_Marketing
Hi folks, Bobcat has launched the Bobber 500 today for Helium 5G. This is an industrial-grade CBRS gateway we co-engineered with FreedomFi. We are currently recruiting Pilot Users to take part in a field trial, where participants will pay for the equipment and receive a Bobber 500, a small cell (Freedomfi One) and an esim download link to help validate the network. If you're interested, fill out this questionnaire and we'll be in touch https://forms.gle/LK9YkHQttHT7fM8P9 (edited)

Bixbite 04/01/2022 10:39 PM

Bixbite
Loved the interview! I have so many questions â€¦. Do you have a blog or website I can check out?
fromenator 04/02/2022 7:41 AM
Yes! to learn more about how 4G/5G tech works, I'd recommend this free site: https://5g.systemsapproach.org/ and this free course: https://www.edx.org/course/introduction-to-magma-cloud-native-wireless-networking
Introduction to Magma: Cloud Native Wireless Networking
Learn about the Magma project, an open source implementation of a mobile network core. Magma supports diverse radio technologies, including LTE, 5G and WiFi, and is particularly relevant for extending network access into remote, sparsely populated areas.
3
perro 04/03/2022 8:00 PM

mixtri 04/24/2022 12:39 PM
I could initiate a project idea at Ericsson to have a radio/baseband for Helium 5g, but I would need some input... Is it a typical ORAN implementation?
12:41
Where can we find a detailed description of the project?
mixtri
Where can we find a detailed description of the project?
fromenator 04/24/2022 12:44 PM
You can get started here: https://docs.helium.com/mine-hnt/full-hotspots/become-a-maker/maker-approval-auditing/. The LTE core is based on the Magma project so if thats what you mean by typical ORAN, yes.
Maker Approval and Auditing Process | Helium Documentation
Due to the overwhelming demand for Hotspots, the community designed and approved a process for adding new, verified manufactures to the ecosystem. This is known has HIP19. With HIP19 in place, companies can submit an application to be reviewed by the community and the DeWi.
2
mixtri 04/24/2022 12:47 PM

I think it is a great idea for Ericsson to join this project. I just need to work a little bit on it to come up with a proposal...

waveform 08/13/2022 2:25 AM
"The initial price per GB of Mobile Network data is suggested to be set at $0.5 per Gigabyte, which means that 1 Helium data credit, when used for data on Mobile Helium DAO will convert to $0.00000003 per LTE packet of 66 bytes." from HIP 53
waveform
